name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, what was the purpose of this report? With this report, we have tried to find another focus in cohesion policy and increase its added value with a new approach to one of Europe's most significant treasures, the mountains. The mountains, which represent about 30% of the territory of the European Union and nearly 17% of citizens. I would like to take this opportunity to thank my colleagues from all political groups for our excellent collaboration with which we have come to this balanced text.  What have we achieved in this document? Our idea of the need to create a programme for the development of mountain regions is common. A European approach can contribute greatly to their convergence, precisely if their advantages and disadvantages as a separate territory are taken into account. This programme could eventually grow into a strategy for the mountains of Europe, which is part of cohesion policy.  Secondly, we advocate the revision and coordination of the instruments existing at European level, which are relevant for the mountains and for the future betting of the mountain dimension in the regional as well as in other Policies of the European Union. Many of the Union's programmes, policies and instruments play a serious indirect role in the mountains and the results they achieve can be increased if the mountain dimension is seriously affected in them.  Thirdly, it is good to have the mountains planned in the next programming period after the creation of a European definition and its placement in the next regulation. Defining the mountains of Europe is a difficult task and many similar definitions exist even in European documents. But in the common agricultural policy, for placing particular emphasis on mountain farming, the definition of mountains is enshrined in the regulation itself – something that is also needed in cohesion policy. Why is such a policy needed? First, the mountains have certain specificities caused by difficult accessibility and vulnerability to climate change. At the same time, they also have numerous riches and real potential for development.  The report therefore focuses on environmental protection and the fight against climate change. This is most important for all mountains in Europe, as it has an effect on tourism and agriculture in many of them.  The mountains are an excellent source of all types of renewable energy – wind, solar, water and biomass. They provide an excellent opportunity to develop the EU's renewable energy policy, which can be concentrated in mountainous regions.  The economy of the mountains still depends largely on crafts, tourism and agriculture. We call for support for small and medium-sized enterprises with a separate approach to mountain regions, precisely to take into account both these and other specificities.  All this politics goes through the education that has its specifics. During the preparation of my report, I saw a number of cases where dual education leads to good results, as in the mountains there is also a need for concentration on crafts and training – especially in sectors that do not lead to environmental pollution.  Last but not least, accessibility and connectivity are also important. The links between the mountains and their adjacent areas are key, as is our proposal for definition.  High-quality internet is key because without it we cannot facilitate the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises and the development of the economy of mountain regions. Attracting so-called "independent professionals", that is, people whose place of work is not fixed, is a very realistic way to improve the demographic situation.  Dear colleagues, I will stop there, wait for your suggestions. I hope we learn a lot of ideas tonight and realize them.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, more and more people are living in fear that modernization and development will destroy their traditions and way of life. Their regions are largely passive, with a smaller and less young population that should be the carrier of development, so they consider new development strategies foreign, misfits and often imposed. Our responsibility to these people is great. We must not allow them to live in fear and be mere observers of development processes, but we must include them to the maximum. This report strongly supports a bottom-up approach and the involvement of local stakeholders from the earliest stages of developing development strategies, and we call on the Commission to provide Guidance to Member States on how to address trust and administrative barriers between different levels of governance. In places with limited resources and capacities and as such can hardly bear the administrative burden of these development tools, the Commission and the Member States must provide additional support, in particular in the form of training and consultation. Experience suggests that the biggest challenges in front of local stakeholders are financial and administrative in nature. Effective integration of funds needs to be worked on to make European funds more accessible and smarter, and we welcome the establishment of a group of independent experts to monitor simplification procedures for beneficiaries of the ESI Funds. We must also combat over-regulation practices that create unnecessary requirements and barriers at all levels, resulting in greater financial and administrative burdens for users. We want as many partners as possible to propose CLLD strategies before 31 December 2017 when the deadline for submission of proposals expires. Until then, we need to achieve greater awareness, ensure the capacity of local stakeholders is strengthened and active participation of social and economic partners and civil society. In this context, it is particularly worrying that for some Member States CLLD represents a mere fulfilment of bureaucratic formalities rather than a true bottom-up approach. Parliament recognises the successes of local action groups in project management and calls for more comprehensive funding and expansion of their scope. We welcome the participation of different partners in the work of LAMs, but only with the quality application of the existing legislative framework according to which it is not possible for one of the interest groups to have more than 49% of the voting rights, thereby reducing the possibility of favouring a single interest group or conflict of interest. Community-led local development can be a major catalyst for employment, especially for young people, through the involvement of SMEs in the implementation of local development projects. Given that unemployment among young people in several Member States is still very high, we consider it a priority for local and regional authorities to provide preconditions for the employment of young people through tax and other incentives. In implementing the ITI, it is also possible to achieve greater involvement of local partners, and the tool itself should not be limited to urban areas. Parliament believes that CLLD and ITI must play an even more important role in future cohesion policy and calls for a bottom-up approach to become an integral part of ITI.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Policy, I present an oral question and a draft resolution under the common name 'Speeding up the implementation of cohesion policy'. The oral question is directly related to the two reports previously submitted and is relevant to the implementation of cohesion policy throughout the planning period.  It has been more than two years since the start of the current cohesion policy programming period and we are already reporting serious delays in its implementation. There have been delays in the adoption of operational programmes, delays in the implementation and implementation of a significant number of ex ante conditionalities fixed in member states' partnership agreements, delays in the appointment of the competent programme and certification bodies by the Member States.  Therefore, in general, we can find a delay in the start of implementation of the programmes, as well as in the preparation and submission of payment documents. There is also a high risk of serious losses by cancelling commitments after 2017 under the M+3 rule.  In recent years, the European Parliament has often called on the European Commission to respond appropriately to the problem of delaying the implementation of cohesion policy. An example of this was the debates on the sixth cohesion report held in this Chamber.  In this context, we have repeatedly stressed the crucial importance of simplifying policy, good governance and coordination and creating synergies with other policies and their financial instruments.  Members of the European Parliament welcomed the establishment of a working group to better implement the 2007-2013 programmes in eight Member States, as well as the establishment by the Commission of a high-level group of independent experts on simplification. Nevertheless, most of the efforts mentioned so far are necessary to overcome the serious challenges of the European Union's cohesion policy.  The European Parliament invites the European Commission to carry out a detailed assessment of progress in the implementation of cohesion policy, to prepare an in-depth analysis of the risks to financial losses by Member States in the event of cancellation of commitments, indicating the specific amounts by country, as well as an analysis of payment forecasts according to the documents submitted by the Member States.  For these reasons, and on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, I would like to ask the European Commission what specific measures it has taken and will take to prevent losses in cancelling commitments. What measures does it take and will take to ensure the full implementation of the payment plan within the 2016 budget and also for the coming years of the planning period? What measures has it taken and what will it take to improve administrative capacity at all levels for the implementation of cohesion policy? Last but not least: how will the European Commission encourage the implementation of the appropriate structural reforms necessary for the effective implementation of cohesion policy? Finally, I would like to ask the Commission what will be the focus of the group's work on better implementation of the programmes for the 2014-2020 programming period?  The European Parliament calls on the European Commission, through the decisions of the Committee on Regional Development, to answer these questions and to provide Parliament with a comprehensive assessment of the situation and the solutions envisaged in order to effectively implement the Cohesion Policy of the European Union, and in order to open a debate on the future of cohesion policy, building on the experience gained in addressing the challenges of this period.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, regarding cohesion policy in mountainous regions, the Commission welcomes Ms Iotova’s report and notes the call for cohesion policy to address the specific challenges faced by mountainous regions. The European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) have a long tradition of supporting regions with specific geographical features, which includes mountain regions. The ESIF Regulation already provides several possibilities to take account of the situation of mountainous regions, such as the modulation of co-financing rates and the use of the new territorial tools, that is: community-led local development and integrated territorial investments.  The ESIF support programmes and strategies specifically targeting mountainous regions have introduced tools for integrated strategies, such as the EU macro-regional strategy for the Alpine Region. The Commission will ask in its monitoring and review meetings with the Member States how they address the specific situation of mountain regions and how the possibilities offered by the ESIF Regulations have been taken up. It is therefore important to make the most of what the current Regulation has to offer, such as the new territorial development tools which I have just mentioned. Regarding the new territorial development tools in cohesion policy: as underlined in Ms Tomašić’s report, integrated territorial investment and community-led local development are decisive for the involvement of local and regional actors. The Commission strongly believes that the introduction of these new territorial tools has been a significant step forward in promoting an integrated place-based approach to territorial development.  I would like to underline that a significant amount of guidance has been provided to Member States and to local actors, both on integrated territorial investment and on community-led local development, to promote the use of these tools. The Commission will continue its strong efforts to share information and share best practices, both with Member States as well as with local actors. These efforts translate the Commission’s willingness to assist Member States in ensuring quality implementation of cohesion policy. Finally, regarding the oral question. With a budget of more than EUR 450 billion and over EUR 215 billion for cohesion policy for 2014-2020, the European Structural and Investment Funds are Europe’s main investment policy tools. To maximise their impact, a reformed cohesion policy framework was advocated and adopted in agreement with the Member States. This framework puts the emphasis on the results, which concentrated funding on priority teams and areas, and investments based on good strategic planning.  The reformed cohesion policy requires good quality implementation subsequent to proper programming, planning and preparatory work. Due to considerable joint efforts with Member States, the Commission adopted half of the cohesion policy programmes already in the course of 2014, in spite of delays in adoption of the regulatory framework. However, under shared management, actual implementation of the programmes is the responsibility of the Member States. The Commission notes that designations of programme authorities took place for less than one quarter of programmes. Furthermore, the number of payment claims received is still low.  Member States are strongly encouraged to continue and to intensify their efforts and there is scope for political pressure in this regard. The Commission provided targeted assistance for eight Member States covered under the Task Force for Better Implementation initiative, reducing significantly the risk of decommitment of funds at closure for the 2007—2013 period to below EUR 5 billion, just over one per cent. The targeted approach, centred on Member States and programmes at risk of implementation, continues in 2014-2020, and that includes closure-related tasks.  Our starting point for discussions with Member States on the funding priorities was rooted in three pillars: the Europe 2020 targets; the relevant country-specific recommendations; and the socio-economic analysis at Member State and regional level. In the coming years, future country-specific recommendations may trigger, where relevant, ESIF programme adjustments. These can also be triggered at the initiative of the Commission, ensuring the Commission’s support for structural reforms in Member States. Regarding administrative capacity, to which the 2014-2020 Regulations have dedicated a thematic objective with a specific allocation, the Commission will continue to assist Member States, including through the newly-established structural reform support service, in carrying out structural reforms in line with the European Semester process and the country-specific recommendations.  Furthermore, Member States can speed up implementation without losing the quality of the spending by using the expanded range of simplified cost options in the 2014-2020 regulatory framework. The reduction in administrative burden this brings about will ensure a more rapid reimbursement of funds, with a greater focus on the results and a lower risk of errors as compared to reimbursement on the basis of real costs.  Regarding automatic decommitment of funds in the third year following commitment, this should be less of a concern in 2014-2020. According to current assumptions, no significant decommitments are expected in this period. This is due to the generic application of the three-year rule instead of the two-year rule across all Member States and to the annual refinancing payments made to the Member States. Nevertheless, timely implementation of the cohesion policy allocation is crucial to avoid an accumulation of payment applications towards the end of the programming period and, first and foremost, to ensure that programmes deliver results on the ground as early as possible.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this joint discussion is welcome because we must ensure that 2016 allows for in-depth exchanges between the Commission and the European Parliament to prepare for future post-2020 regulations, and this will greatly facilitate the negotiations to come. From my point of view, three areas seem to me to be a priority. Firstly, there needs to be a simplification, particularly in access to European funding for the final beneficiaries, since you know that the complexity means that many beneficiaries are discouraged, and this also feeds the growing disaffection for the European Union. Secondly, we will have to think about excluding from the calculation of national deficits the investments made to co-finance cohesion policy, and in particular those implemented in the resolution of the migration challenge and for the integration of refugees. In this regard, I believe that we need to start thinking about sanctions for those states that benefit greatly from the Structural Funds and which are constantly violating the values of the European Union and fundamental rights. You'll have to hit where it hurts. Thirdly, the outermost regions must be given particular importance and the full consequences of the recent decision of the European Court of Justice must be drawn.

name: Monika VANA
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I too welcome the opportunity to debate cohesion policy here in the plenary of the European Parliament. As the Commissioner put it in a nutshell, cohesion policy is the European Union's main investment tool. As shadow rapporteur for the report 'Cohesion policy in mountain areas', I would like to thank Mrs Iotova very much for her work. It is important for the EU to find new ways of better supporting mountain regions. And there are some levers, particularly on the part of cohesion policy, that can be better used.  We know that there can be no one-size-fits-all model that can be applied anywhere. But I think mountainous regions all face similar challenges – be it climate change, or people's access to public services, educational institutions, the labour market. The role of women and the situation of women in mountainous regions of my group, the Greens, are particularly important here. Women, especially in mountainous regions, have lower employment opportunities and a lower employment rate compared to men and are less integrated into traditional sectors of the economy. And when they are employed, as the studies from these regions show, they are either part-time or in low-paid jobs. I believe that we, as Members of the European Parliament, must take up this challenge in particular.  There is, for example, a very good project, which we would also like to mention, an Internet project called WOMEN-ALPnet, which explicitly aims to promote the participation of women in sustainable development in the Alpine region. We are also pleased that the report takes particular account of the role of glaciers and the role of the mountains as eco- and water systems. According to calculations, the glaciers in Europe are expected to have melted down by 2050. The EU must counteract this fatal development: I think we are much more dependent on our ecosystems than many people think; it is our task to preserve them.  So there are some very positive points in the report. However, we will also ask for two split or separate votes in the vote, especially as far as the wording is concerned. In the report, the mountains are sometimes described as an obstacle through which it is essential to build roads or other transport links. We Greens naturally take a different view here: mountains are primarily vulnerable ecosystems for us, in which any construction project – especially in the area of infrastructure – can cause massive damage. Man should adapt to the mountain and not the other way around.  We will ask for a second split vote in the formulation that solar and wind turbines could affect the landscape. We Greens, too, naturally see this differently. In any case, we must ensure that – and this is also included in this report – mountains are not misused as material storage facilities for the surrounding regions, but are perceived and supported as fragile ecosystems that have a major impact on our well-being. As an Austrian, I would like to highlight the Alpine Convention in a positive way.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on Wednesday we will be voting on important reports on innovative instruments and a motion for a resolution on speeding up the implementation of cohesion policy.
