Finally, we will never agree on the link introduced in this programming between so-called sound economic governance and the Structural Funds. Let me give you an example: structural funds and structural reforms in my country are absolutely inconceivable, everything is nothing but participation, sharing and transparency.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – We are talking about cohesion policy today. Cohesion means cohesion, attraction, keeping together. Dear people, that is the opposite of the EU! The EU is falling apart. The EU is disintegrating. Even the biggest EU fanatics can no longer deny this and no longer deny it. Because the EU is a bad luck magnet and whether you look at the refugee problem, the euro crisis or trade treaties like TTIP, it leads to one major failure. Last year on 5 May, my dear colleague Hans Jansen died, and I would like to quote him here because he always said that 'the EU has made Europe an incontinent continent'.  The EU has made Europe an incontinent continent.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European In article 3 of the Treaty on European Union, the promotion of territorial cohesion is designated as a task. Well, in light of that, let's look at the results of the previous budget cycle. The gap between the so-called centre countries and the periphery, especially the former socialist countries, has not decreased, but has increased. Nevertheless, cohesion funds will be 8.4% less in this cycle. It speaks for itself. In this situation, the commission's proposal to make it easier for the European Commission to implement operational programmes in order to avoid suspension of payments should be supported. However, let us add that a distinction must be made between problems arising from excessive bureaucracy and a reasonable suspicion of corrupt use.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank rapporteur Ruža Tomašić for her good cooperation in this report. The absorption of European funds has been a constant concern for all Member States. In this respect, the European Commission and the European Parliament have had as their objectives the identification of mechanisms and procedures to simplify this process which Member States complain of as extremely cumbersome and difficult.  I therefore welcome the identification of new territorial development instruments in cohesion policy 2014-2020 and the strengthening of the two mechanisms, namely integrated territorial investments and community-led local development. They will contribute significantly to economic, social and territorial cohesion, but above all, and I stress, above all, the creation of new jobs. It is also very important to create a framework within which it is possible to combine flows of funds with local initiatives, so that we can work with a strengthening of the capacity of communities to organise and implement projects, which take into account the needs of citizens and always from the bottom up. The implementation process requires adequate identification of resources and strategic advantages, both from local and regional authorities and effective cooperation between rural and urban areas, with a view to strengthening regional competitiveness.  Participatory, performance-based budgeting must aim for the efficiency of European funds so that there is as much added value as possible. However, the European Parliament and the Commission must further identify the mechanisms by which Member States are obliged to simplify their process of absorbing European funds and at the same time expressly prohibit them from creating additional conditionalities beyond European provisions.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, the implementation of these two instruments, the ITI and the CLLD, is guided by economic, social and territorial cohesion, but also by urban and city development with the aim of achieving the 2020 Strategy targets. And no one better than local authorities will be able to indicate the territorial objectives of their communities, in a logic of national understanding, thus carrying out european cohesion policy. This requires the definition of strategies in the first stages of the implementation process with regional and local actors, in particular at the level of specific and specialised training, technical and financial support resulting from an effective partnership between the regions or Member States and the European Union. Hence the importance of cooperation between local, regional, national and European authorities to ensure the consecration of technical assistance budgets for local authorities, thus avoiding duplication of existing structures. We are talking about the empowerment of regional and local structures as being fundamental to the full implementation of the policy of economic, social and territorial cohesion, which should, in our view, pay particular attention to projects committed to adapting localities and regions to the new demographic reality and in countering the resulting imbalances.  Above all, we ensure that the LAGs have 49% of the voting rights so that the basic principle is made to the top and that is to bring the citizen closer to Europe. It means that this Parliament understands and strengthens the fundamental role of local government, which encourages the involvement of regional and local governments in the regional and territorial development strategy. For our part, we are committed to ensuring that all kinds of European funding reaches all European regions, including the local power of the outermost regions which are often less privileged in hearing and deciding European investments.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: – ITIs and CLLD initiatives can be used to implement Europe's good agenda at local level. But to succeed, it is crucial that local partners are seen as key players. Trust is the magic word. Above all, Member States should not be afraid to re-enern. In Europe, let us experiment more often with these new instruments for territorial development.  We are also debating today whether to speed up the implementation of cohesion policy. I am particularly curious to see what lessons the European Commission has learned. What will the European Commission propose to be able to invest from the outset in the next programme period after 2020 with the resources of the European structural and investment funds?

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Mr President, integrated territorial investment and participatory local development are important tools for territorial development, but they are not sufficiently implemented. It is stated that it is urgent for Member States to make greater use of them, but that is precisely where the problem arises. Without much more real and effective participation of local and regional actors, political and social, the effectiveness of both tools loses effectiveness, meaning and quality. And this is especially relevant when it comes to cross-border cooperation. Even if it involves questioning the existing framework and, in the same line as several Members have just said, local and regional actors must participate and act before the implementation phase, i.e. in design, selection and decision-making, not just in the consultation. We need more information and training, but also a clearer and more ambitious political orientation.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as you know, territorial cohesion integrates the objectives of economic and social cohesion into the current legal order. It is a question of translating at territorial level the objectives of balanced and sustainable development which Article 2 of the Treaty assigns to the Union. Among the regions concerned, particular attention is paid to mountainous regions with serious and permanent natural handicaps. It is necessary to ensure that these regions have the necessary resources, ensuring that, by virtue of the geographical handicap they suffer from, they are recognised as deserving of enhanced protection, which will determine the conditions for privileged access to economic resources (understood as financial grants) made available by cohesion policy. For these reasons, the reference in this report to EFSI as an instrument of mere financial engineering, the effectiveness of which has not yet been demonstrated, cannot be considered acceptable. For the future, Parliament must – and I am sure it will – promote this body, which comes from the territories, and it translates into the need to ensure an adequate distribution of resources and opportunities.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: Mr President, we find in this project your willingness to interfere in imposing the views of the European Union in every corner of the European territory and in all areas on sometimes surprising subjects that we would not think of at first. This is the case with your point 49 and gender inequalities. I thought I'd find the problems of mountain areas elsewhere, which proves that your projects are above all ideological and catch-all. I will just talk about agriculture, which is an area I am familiar with.  We remain attached to the sovereign strategist states and to the cross-border collaborations between these sovereign states, precisely, especially since behind this project lies your destructive federalism of nations. In addition, how can we establish a common strategy for these many and diverse territories? Each mountainous area has its own unique features. In the Alps in the Alps, we find different cultures. In the Hautes-Alpes, for example, where employment is primarily seasonal, livestock farming rubs shoulders with arboreal crops - I am thinking of apples - two sectors, therefore, with totally different needs. The diversity of mountain cultures and their richness, this is what makes them unique.  The French Alpine region therefore seems to me to be a laboratory for the agriculture of tomorrow. The farms are medium-sized or even small, specialized but focused on the local market and short circuits, far from your intensive agriculture projects to conquer international markets.  Regional farmers, on the other hand, seek to value their products. There are many appellations of controlled origin, which explains the development of organic farming and short-circuit marketing, which generates more than half of the turnover. The number of farms in these regions has fallen by 28% while the average farm area has increased by 10%: again, we find the result of a CAP that pushes concentration.  That is not what farmers are looking for at all, and I think it is not the right model for mountain areas.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, today's reports and debate on the European Union's so-called 'cohesion policy' show that the mechanisms for direct, and indeed combined, financing of business groups at local level are being strengthened. Under the cloak of combating bureaucracy and so-called local development, the funds that are being cut savagely today at the expense of even the most basic popular needs are given, in summary procedures, north to business groups in the form of free money for new areas of profitability. It is typical that for mountain regions, whose populations are suffering from dramatic shortages of public health, welfare, education infrastructure, the European Parliament, the European Union and its governments, cohesion funds should be directed to renewable energy projects in order to deliver large and fast profits to groups in the sector. Such is the European Union and the capitalist development you advertise, built on the ruins of labour rights, poverty and impoverishment. Development to its advantage the people can bring only by their struggle against monopolies and their associations, taking into their own hands the power and wealth it produces.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, in the resolution on accelerating the implementation of cohesion policy, we point out that cohesion policy has changed significantly for the 2014-2020 perspective. A lot of novelties have been introduced, from the thematic concentration to the focus on results, the need for greater coordination, especially with the economic policy of ex-ante preconditions and everything else. The news means improvements, but they are also looking for new knowledge, additional work on preparations. Countries should have programmed differently and applied the new approach, established new governance structures, new procedures, new information systems. All this has led to the situation that in 2016 in the third year of perspective 2014-2020, implementation in most is just beginning and the risk of decommitment occurs. I heard Commissioner Vella say that because n+3 the risk of decommitment is lower because we previously had an n+2 rule, however, the question is whether states really have an n+3 rule since the advance is much lower than the earlier perspective and that the operational programs were adopted too late, and the ex-ante requirements have not yet been met. With this resolution, we do not want to blame anyone or look for the culprit for the late start of implementation and the risk of loss of funds. We are not asking for any more funds or extension of the n+3 rules. We are looking for the following: accelerated simplification of rules and procedures, approaching the needs of end-users, more communication to increase the visibility of cohesion policy among citizens, early start of programming so that the system is ready to start implementing in practice in the first year of perspective, not just theoretically in regulation. The first message is that we are looking for policy stability. We cannot expect early implementation if for each perspective we introduce completely new rules for programming and implementation of a new governance structure, new procedures, new information systems. Another message is that Member States must work to improve financial management systems, address problems that are an obstacle to the preparation and implementation of projects, and are often deeply structural in the Member States themsies themsies and therefore carry out structural reforms, become faster and more flexible and strengthen administrative capacities. In addition, the resolution seeks a greater role for national parliaments and stronger coordination and communication between us, the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Member States. In the end, we are proud of cohesion policy and want to make it even closer and closer to our citizens.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: – Mr President, I wanted to concentrate on the new tools available for cohesion policy. The 2014 to 2020 cohesion policy puts greater emphasis on a bottom-up approach and that is why we put in place new tools such as community-led local development and integrated territorial investments.  All these new tools are very much welcome but I am not sure how widely they are being used in Member States and regions. Indeed, when you read the report, it does say that there seems to be a lack of trust between the different levels of government and I believe this is particularly the case between central government and local and regional government. I believe that central government in many cases believes that local and regional government do not have the capacity to plan and deliver programmes.  Also, of course, Member States in many cases put in place many additional burdens, the so-called gold-plating.  Therefore I believe it would be useful if the Commission could monitor the use of these new tools to see how far they have been used currently but also to learn lessons for cohesion policy post—2020.

name: Julia REID
text: – Mr President, I rise to discuss the topic of integrated territorial investment. As the name suggests, it is yet another part of the EU strategy to erode away national and local identities. As with many EU policies, this is disguised as having an economic purpose, when in reality it is about political control. Jean Monnet himself openly bragged about how political federalist policies could be disguised in this way – and that is the exact word he used, epitomising the lies and deceit that so characterised the EU and its supporters. This report brags about how cost—effective this is, but the EU does not have a good track record when it comes to fiscal efficiency. We are in Strasbourg, the bi-location of the Parliament, being one of the many ways in which the EU shamelessly wastes money. But this is not just about money: this is about propaganda. As a referendum approaches in my country, the EU claims it gives us lots of money. It even forces recipients to erect propaganda signs thanking the EU for giving us money, despite the fact that it was ours in the first place. There are some parts of the UK where these ghastly propaganda posters seem to be ever present. The public in my country have seen through this, and the citizens of other EU countries will see through it soon enough. In Britain, our own social cohesion is at risk as uncontrolled migration from the EU leads to greater pressure on housing, schools and rationing of healthcare. Luckily, in the UK, we have an opportunity to rectify this by voting to leave the EU in the referendum on 23 June.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: – The EPP has asked for this debate, and Mrs Maletić has already said a few words about the question and the resolution. I'll take one point out. Commissioner Vela, you are a portfolio holder for fisheries. All fishermen know you in Europe. That's where it's clear. But what is a little out of the way in cohesion policy is that this is a shared responsibility with the Member States. In the end, they really struggle to show that the European stars are looking after the projects. Joint financing, joint strategy, EU 2020, growth, jobs, sustainability, that's what we work for. But at the end of the day, I find it sells badly.  I would like to ask you, in view of what is to come, namely a mid-term review and a discussion about the future, to communicate better. Be good and tell it, unpack better and show it. It happens in regions, it happens in cities, but then... I sometimes come to projects where, after two or three years, the EU's signs have long since faded. I ask for a better way to communicate, as you do at the EFSI, for example. Can you go into that?

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank our three rapporteurs for the work they have done.  In recent years, despite what we have heard here from some colleagues, cohesion policy has confirmed itself as one of the most important investment instruments in the European Union. It has provided opportunities for citizens, businesses and local and regional authorities to converge towards the economies of other countries (and this has succeeded), but also to emerge from the crisis and revive growth. It must also remain one of the pillars of the process of European integration for the future.  Specifically, I would like to say something about mountain areas: it is clear that specific attention is needed given the special features of these territories. The development of mountain areas can also be achieved through the use of the instruments we have discussed and will be decisive in enabling areas with different but integrated characteristics to develop harmoniously. I would like to say to the Commissioner, as chairman of the Montagna intergroup, that we are campaigning for a European agenda for rural and mountain areas, and I think we will soon have the opportunity to talk to him about it. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I just have a quick question. Would you agree with my characterisation that cohesion policy, realistically, is the taking of money in tax, from taxpayers in net contributor countries like the UK, to be spent across Europe to improve governance and cohesion for a closer EU project in years to come? Would you agree with that characterisation of exactly what this is about?

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Of course. I believe that you know that the single market favours the richest countries, and cohesion policy is precisely the instrument that enables the regions of the poorest countries to converge towards similar income levels and to be able to withstand competition from the strongest countries. Without cohesion policy, it would be impossible to have a single market that is not to the total detriment of the poorest countries of the Union. Of course someone may not be interested, but I believe that this is one of the fundamental objectives of our being together.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, it is a pleasure to be speaking here on a Monday night and to have a minute and a half to discuss cohesion policy. I find it interesting that an MEP from the West Midlands of the United Kingdom is here talking about mountainous regions. We do not have very many mountains in my part of the UK, which is Wolverhampton and Dudley. We have a few canals, but we do not have mountains. What we do have is mountains of debt; what we do have are peaks of demand for people to go to doctors’ surgeries; and what we do have are valleys of despair of people in our region who cannot get into work, who cannot get to see a doctor and who cannot get their kids into the right school. We have all of these things, and we can thank the EU and its cohesion policy for much of it, because the reasons why we cannot have these things is because our industry has been destroyed – we were the home of the industrial revolution – and we are subjected to mass, uncontrolled immigration into our area, which means we do not have the places for people to go into the schools or the houses or the hospitals. So really, the only mountain that the people in the West Midlands really want to talk about is ‘Mount Freedom’. I want them to ascend to the pinnacle of ‘Mount Freedom’ on our referendum day and have a look at the view, when we can look at all of you across the Channel and say ‘Hi guys, the view is lovely, but we love it at the top, and we love it being free.’ (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" question. – I have had the pleasure of being in the region where Mr Etheridge is from and what struck me there was the enormous - and I am sorry to have to say so - poverty. What I'm wondering now, Mr. Etheridge, how do you, as a MEP, as an elected official, explain that to the people there? How do you do that? By saying, we take your tax money and we take it all over the world, no matter, Zimbabwe, everywhere, but we take the money from you, when you are already so heavy at the bottom of society?

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card answer. – This is the injustice. We are constantly hearing in this place that the UK is so wealthy. Yes, take the money from the UK and redistribute it as all socialists wish to do. However, the area of the UK that elected myself and my colleague here, James Carver, from the West Midlands as well, we have some of the poorest people across Europe in our area. These people cannot afford the things that others may take for granted. They cannot get work, and when you take the money that could be spent on their schools, their hospitals, and you redistribute it, as you see fit, you do a disservice to some of the poorest people in the whole of Europe and it is a shame.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Dear friends! One third of the European budget goes back to the Member States as structural funds. That is why I am surprised that today, when we debate the state of cohesion policy, the Council bench remains empty, especially as I think that, on Europe Day today, the Council would have been well advised to be present here. The state of cohesion and structural policy at the moment must be of concern to us. The rules for the new funding period have been in place since 2014, but most Member States are still working on the projects of the previous funding period.  Important key elements of the new funding period will not be followed in the Member States: the promotion of the territorial and urban dimensions of cohesion policy, with local development measures implemented by the local population, is not being implemented in many Member States. In this way, however, European policy and solidarity on the ground cannot be seen. I do not hope that these and other shortcomings and delays in the implementation of the new funding period are intended to end cohesion policy by 2020, because it is no longer proving to be effective. In order to dispel this impression, the Commission, as well as the Member States, should now begin to speed up cohesion policy in the new framework and implement the measures. There is still time for this, and I hope it will not pass by uselessly.

name: Jens NILSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you very much for the floor, Mr President. I would like to add two things to this debate. The first is tourism. Tourism, which was presented in this House a few weeks ago in the committee responsible, namely the Committee on Transport — a manifesto for how we develop tourism in Europe. When I read the manifesto, it might as well have been presented in the REGI, because very many of our regions have prioritised tourism as a basic industry that is important for creating jobs and jobs in their regions. This applies to cities, large and small towns, regions and mountain areas, such as my own mountain area in northern Sweden, which is now one, a winter sports centre. We have used European funds to develop tourism, and we can do this much better, so I look forward to regi also cooperating with TRAN on tourism issues. Then I would like to add to the social economy, as chairman of the intergroup. There are lots of cooperatives and associations that are engaged in active local development work that requires more support than they receive today.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Cohesion policy is the main investment policy. In many places in Europe, this policy is the main source of investment, creating new jobs and contributing to growth. Entrepreneurs, local governments, NGOs, many other beneficiaries are waiting for these funds. We have half of 2016 and we are debating a slow start and insufficient implementation. In my opinion, we should already be setting the direction of the next financial perspective and working on it. Speeding up deployment is only possible through simplification. We need more trust at every level of management and implementation of the Structural Funds. Acceleration will not be possible without strengthening the capacity of local and regional authorities. This is particularly evident in the example of new tools, such as community-led local development. They have great potential, but unfortunately complex procedures mean that they have not been fully exploited. When making further recommendations, we should first listen to the beneficiaries of cohesion policy.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, cohesion policy reflects one of the most visible and useful added values of the European Union – solidarity. Based on quality projects, we help the less developed. Cohesion policy has proven to be the most important source of public investment in times of austerity policy. The facts are clear: in the past budget period, GDP per capita in the so-called convergent regions increased by 2.2% and 600,000 new jobs were generated. 200,000 SMEs and 77,800 'start-ups' received direct financial assistance. More than 80,000 research projects are supported. That is why cohesion policy should continue in the next budgetary period: thematically focused, with a better urban-rural relationship, simpler procedures, greater efficiency and better communication with citizens. I support the proposed measures to accelerate the implementation of cohesion policy and the reports we are discussing today. But I point out that our islands should also be discussed as much as mountainous areas. Recommendations from the recently adopted resolution on islands should therefore be taken into account.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Mr President, we are once again concluding here today that cohesion policy is the European Union's main and most reliable investment tool. But it is implemented with many problems, many obstacles and, in many cases, with low efficiency. For example, in my country, in Greece, two years later the absorption of the NSRF programmes begins with difficulty, and, fortunately, today the first of the guarantee programmes for innovative enterprises, a synergy between the private sector and Horizon 2020, was signed. What can we do? First of all, we encourage Member States to continue synergies, either with the European Fund for Strategic Investments, with the SME-specific instrument or with horizon 2020. And especially in countries like Greece, this is necessary to guarantee the country's risk. In order for banks to finally do their job, i.e. to give liquidity to small and medium-sized enterprises. However, it is also necessary for us to proceed immediately with the simplification of the regulations. Small and medium-sized entrepreneurs cannot avoid any Community money and resort to banks, which refuse to finance them in the end. We need to simplify the tools and push the Member States to do their job reliably.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur and the author for some really excellent news, but in my short speech I want to address mountainous areas, because they represent up to 30% of the territory of the European Union and are currently facing very serious problems. As a result of extreme conditions and remoteness, mountainous areas are depopulated and quality of life is reduced.  I believe that cohesion policy will also help to stem population migration, improve employment and thus quality of life in mountainous areas. Although there are major differences between mountainous regions, I believe that the European Union and its Member States will help mountainous areas in all aspects of EU policies, including cohesion policy, in order to overcome the current challenges. I will vote in favour of all three reports.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The discussion on the level of implementation seriously affects how cohesion policy will look after 2020. If this discussion leads to the conclusion that there is a lack of effectiveness, this will lead to a reduction in the policy or a reduction in its importance. Therefore, there is an urgent need to answer the questions as to why we are dealing with poor implementation: is it because procedures are too complex, or because certain rules are still not ready, or because national rules are not adapted, or because beneficiaries are somehow to blame? The answer to these questions is really very urgent. We, Parliament, need it if we are to work on new solutions. The proposals should lead to an immediate revision of the budget. We have three more years to go and we cannot wait.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Mr President, Europe's mountain ranges stretch across the territory of several Member States, including third countries. In these areas, mountain agriculture, forestry and tourism are important sectors for the identity and culture of mountain regions, making an important contribution to employment and the continued diversification of the economies of these regions. It is beneficial for Europe to develop multiple agricultural production in relation to the development of tourism and activities related to environmental protection and an adequate structuring of the food chain in mountain areas. I support the rapporteur's proposal to initiate a debate on the introduction of special labels for mountain food at European Union level. Mountain areas have significant potential for the production of high-quality food, which will allow for better promotion and marketing of agricultural products and their inclusion among the general tourist products of a geographical area.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the UK recently experienced a very concrete example of the importance of EU assistance through regional funds because during December 2015 the UK was hit by the extra-tropical cyclone storm Desmond, followed by storms Eva and Frank, causing severe flooding in the north of England and Scotland well into January. Extensive damage was caused to homes, communities and businesses. Following intense pressure from the Labour Party, the UK Government finally applied for EU solidarity funds in February 2016, on the eve of the deadline, and we are now waiting for the first payments to be made in order to support affected communities. I represent a beautiful, isolated, rural and mountainous area in the northwest of England. So I know first-hand the positive impact that the EU cohesion policy can have on sustainable economic, social and cultural development of the regions and I am very proud to say that the EU flag is proudly fluttering outside my office in Workington Town Hall today. I do not need to repeat what my colleagues have already said, demonstrating the positive impact, but I would like to say that proper support for social and cultural cohesion policies should be more prevalent.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the dialogue between Parliament and the Commission is crucial at a time when the foundations for the review of cohesion policies are being laid and the regional policy that will be discussed.  I am sure that I am prepared to listen to Parliament, and I am also pleased about this, because the link between members of parliament and the territories that elected them is very close. And it is often on us that the administrators pour out their frustrations at the inability or impossibility of using the instruments of cohesion policy, which, even for them, now represent survival.  What is not working or has not worked in cohesion policy is what the local authorities, which are suffocated by the Stability Pact, are telling us. They cannot find the resources for cofinancing and at the same time to comply with budgetary constraints. Flexibility is the key to speeding up cohesion policy and an economy that needs growth and development investments that produce jobs first and all, and we must never forget that.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European In the debate on EU cohesion policy, we cannot go without talking about the fact that in some Member States EU funds are not for the well-being of the people, not for the development of the economy, but for the well-being and enrichment of the few close to the government. This is also the case in Hungary, where, due to suspected corruption cases, the European Commission has been forced to suspend 10 of the 15 EU operational programmes in Hungary in the last few years. In some of these cases, such as the suspected corruption of the Son-in-Law of the Hungarian Prime Minister, even the EU Anti-Fraud Office has opened an investigation. It's a huge amount of money, a huge penalty. In the end, fines of up to HUF 700 billion, amounting to 10% of EU funds, may have to be paid. However, this fine will be paid by the Hungarian taxpayers and not by those who fraudulently received the funds. We therefore call on the Commission, on the one hand, to speed up the investigation into these matters and, on the other hand, to establish legislation that will result in criminal penalties for the culprits and not for the taxpayers of a Member State.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with a budget of over EUR 350 billion, the European Union's cohesion policy is the main source of public investment in some Member States. The objectives of strengthening growth and employment are achieved through coherent interaction within the framework of the various economic policies of the European Union. Youth unemployment is undoubtedly the most pressing problem among the Member States. Cohesion policy, and in particular local and territorial development strategies, must address this problem as a priority and with innovative instruments. Member States must use the financial instruments of cohesion policy for projects aimed at creating opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises and promoting investment, sustainable and inclusive growth and social investment, as well as contributing to poverty reduction and promoting social inclusion. Finally, it is essential to give greater impetus to participatory local development instruments and integrated territorial investments in order to allow a bottom-up approach to cohesion policies, through the participation of local actors.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, mountain areas make up about 30% of the territory of the Union and many of them are rich in natural resources and renewable energy sources. They could therefore contribute to strengthening the development of the Member States of the Union. Of course, many mountain areas have insufficient accessibility and few employment opportunities while, in countries such as Greece, with the intervention of the troika, the primary sector has been dismantled and farmers' pensions have been butchered. At the same time, the implementation of the rural development programme for Greece in 2014-2020 should be accelerated, as it includes funding of EUR 4.7 billion. This will cover 10.3% of agricultural land for biodiversity conservation, 12.1% for improving water management and 10.7% for soil management. Moreover, in view of the poverty and social exclusion affecting Greece, Union funds should be increased and emphasis placed on underdeveloped areas.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, European regional aid and social funding make a difference. They bring people into the world of work, they help the vulnerable in our societies and they stop communities from being left behind. Examples in my own constituency include helping older people in Luton, the Prince’s Trust to help young people who have dropped out of education in Chelmsford, and helping rural businesses to set up in the Waveney Valley. This is social Europe. Altogether, the East of England will receive GBP 250 million in the next five years – in Norfolk and Suffolk alone supporting 5 000 businesses and creating 2 000 jobs. Those in the British referendum who dismiss this simply as our own money should recognise that these EU funds leverage additional match funding that would not otherwise be attracted, include transnational partnerships where we can build bonds and learn from each other, and foster genuine European-level innovation for the benefit of all.  If we leave the EU and lose this funding, do Eurosceptics really argue that a British Government which has cut so much would give us any of that money back? Already the East of England is collaborating with Lower Austria, South Sweden, Prague and Helsinki on future plans for cohesion policy post-2020.  Tonight’s debate is about the future post-2020, and my own contribution seeks to argue that the United Kingdom must be part of it: British regions are stronger in Europe.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, cohesion policy is not a new theme, it is an obligation in the Treaty. However, within the framework of the general cohesion policy, the policy for the mountain region is a special one, and I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and all the colleagues who have worked on this report. In my country and in many other countries in the European Union, we have mountain areas. Mountain regions face relief-specific hardships, often access to resources is made harder, with additional transport costs, climate change, there is no human resource, training, no infrastructure. That is why I believe that special policies must be made in special places, and I particularly appreciate and support the proposal to harmonise agricultural policies with those of tourism, with those of the development of traditional, artisanal, artisanal craft products. And I particularly support the rapporteur's proposal that both the Member States and the Commission make regular assessments in order to conduct an appropriate funding policy. In mountain areas we must support in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, manufacturing and tourism. Attracting young people to this area is extremely important.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Mr President, mountain areas in Europe must be protected and supported in their development. Therefore, dedicated programmes must be provided and local initiatives to help the population of these areas must be integrated into a coherent and consistent strategy at European level. Personally, I lived in the mountain areas of Romania, specifically in Transylvania. And so I can give you the example of the area of the Apuseni Mountains, an extremely beautiful region with a potential still unfruitful, with over half a million inhabitants. The priorities of this area apply to all mountain areas: infrastructure development, access to education and health, job creation or investment attraction. Communities in European mountain areas are a tradition for our countries and deserve to be treated with respect and support so that the lives of the citizens there do not differ from those of other European citizens. In this respect, cohesion policy plays an important role, and this mechanism makes it possible to close the gap. We need to strengthen cohesion policy in order to become more accessible and to have a greater impact in all these areas.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the European Commission I would like to thank the honourable Members Iotova and Tomašić for their reports and also the honourable Members who participated in this debate. The legal and policy framework for the European Structural and Investment Funds for 2014-2020 has entailed a major leap forward in taking account of the diversity of European regions, in particular their mountainous areas, and developing specific tools to exploit the potential of this diversity. For this new funding cycle, Member States are required to set out in their partnership agreements an integrated approach to address the specific needs of geographical areas suffering from severe and permanent handicaps. Furthermore, they have at their disposal new instruments to reflect these specificities. I have mentioned modulation of EU co-financing rates but also integrated territorial investments and community-led local development. The Commission strongly believes that the introduction of these new territorial tools will facilitate promoting an integrated place-based approach to territorial development in cohesion policy as well as to foster a bottom-up approach. But, following the adoption of the ESIF programmes, now it is up to Member States to take up these new tools and to translate our funds into to growth and jobs for European regions and European citizens. It is their responsibility, but the Commission is actively supporting them in this endeavour. We are jointly examining those programmes where particular efforts are needed. We have set up a high-level group on simplification. We are supporting administrative capacity, providing a great deal of guidance so that they can accelerate implementation without having to compromise on quality. I noted that many mentioned capacity building, and it is worth mentioning the several administrative capacity building actions proposed by the Commission in areas such as public procurement and state aid and the TAIEX-REGIO Peer 2 Peer platform designed to help officials involved in the management of the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund to exchange knowledge and to exchange good practices. Also, the newly established structural reform support service will assist Member States in carrying out structural reforms. It was also suggested that the Commission needs to communicate its policies better such as FC and ESIF complementarities and the Commission recently published a brochure on FC and ESIF complementarities which is available on the Commission’s website as well as a technical website on the same topic. The Commission is confident that this work will bear fruit, allowing investments to result and sustainable growth for people on the ground, which is after all our common objective to us all. I can assure you the Commission will spare no energy in these efforts. Finally, I would like to thank you very much for your very valuable comments and suggestions, which the Commission duly notes.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the colleagues in this chamber for the high appreciation they gave to the report which, together with the shadow rapporteurs, we have produced for the mountainous regions. In fact, there is a great concern in most of these speeches, and that is the concern about the depopulation of these regions in Europe.  This trend is not limited only in more peripheral countries, it is not limited to countries such as Bulgaria and Romania, where entire mountain municipalities disappear. One of the scariest statistics I came across in my own country was that in a quarter of the settlements in the mountainous regions there are no children under 14. Although weaker, rich countries also see a trend of depopulation.  With the loss of mountain municipalities, not only the ecosystem services on which we all depend are lost. The rich culture of the mountains is lost, as well as excellent development opportunities. And that is why I want to address the European Commission tonight.  Dear Colleagues, when making the new multiannual financial framework, when we are now doing a general review of the current financial framework, let us put special attention and emphasis on the mountainous regions of Europe. This is an inexhaustible wealth for all of us, and in the future generations will not forgive us if we do not pay special attention to these regions now.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr. President, Mr. Vella, colleagues and colleagues, I would like to thank everyone who participated in the drafting of this report and all those who will support him in the vote. In order to restore citizens' trust in institutions and ensure the sustainable development of Europe while preserving our specificity, it is of utmost importance to give local residents the opportunity to participate directly in creating the future of their communities, and I hope that most colleagues and the Commission will recognise this as well. I will continue to monitor the implementation of these development tools in the Member States and help LAMs in Croatia, as this approach to the development of local communities is a true guarantee of a sustainable future aligned with the wishes of our citizens.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(1) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 11 May 2016.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – Mountainous regions make up a significant part of the European Union's territory, offering a wide range of opportunities to achieve the EU's objectives of employment, cohesion and the environment. I would like to draw the Commission's attention to the importance of developing tourism in order to combat problems such as unemployment, emigration and ageing in the mountainous region. Today, there are 25 million Europeans working in the sector, the proportion of under-24s is three times higher than in other sectors, but tourism cannot be considered a quality career enterprise. For this trend to change, it is primarily necessary to encourage opportunities for professional career development and to address remuneration issues.  The Commission should also develop concrete proposals to improve easier access to education (mainly ICT-based), lifelong learning and mobility in mountainous regions. In order to make mountainous areas more attractive to economic activities, the Commission and the Member States need to work together to allocate funds from cohesion and investment funds to the regions. In order to reduce youth unemployment and increase the efficiency of SMEs, this should be of paramount importance.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – In Romania, the mountain region covers more than 30% of the country's area. This region is characterized by a slow but constant process of depopulation. The lack of adequate infrastructure, climatic conditions and limited supply of occupations lead young people not to want to stay in mountain areas. Livestock farming, logging, harvesting berries are no longer crafts to incentivise young people to stay in these areas. The European Union can therefore use the Structural Funds and in particular the Cohesion Fund to finance programmes to support the development of mountain tourism, while at the same time developing infrastructure for access to mountain areas. Only the combination of traditional trades in the mountain area with the development of infrastructure and mountain tourism can ensure a decent living for those who want to settle and live in mountain areas.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – Mountain regions occupy about 30% of the total territory of the European Union. Due to extreme conditions and distance, mountainous areas face problems such as depopulation and population ageing, potentially disrupting the natural cycle of generations. Significant differences are emerging between mountainous regions, which is why I think there is a need for concerted action between policies and sectors, both between different mountainous areas and within individual mountainous areas. Due to their specifics, in particular the numerous and diversified renewable energy sources and their dependence on resource efficiency and energy efficiency, mountainous regions can contribute to the development of new technologies and innovation in general.  There is no clear definition of mountain regions in EU regional policy and the definition used under the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development is not suitable for cohesion policy and cannot be used as such to effectively manage this policy. This is why I believe that eu policies need to create special access to mountainous regions. These regions need help to overcome challenges such as climate change, economic development, employment, environmental protection and other similar challenges.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European Union's cohesion policy is one of the main factors of solidarity development in its territory. Designed to combat asymmetries and break the gap in access to opportunities for European citizens by the volume of resources it mobilises (more than €350 billion by 2020), cohesion policy is a key tool for reversing the cycle of stagnation in which the EU plunged after the financial crisis started in 2008.  In view of its importance, the process of implementing cohesion policy should be given particular attention by the European Union. Delays in implementation and the difficulty in combining it with other tools to support development, growth, employment and investment are missed opportunities when the EU is experiencing difficulties requiring the mobilisation of all available resources.  It is essential to speed up the implementation of cohesion funds, facilitate their combination with other funds and reward good governance in the implementation of resources by intelligently applying the principle of subsidiarity, favouring local implementation in the framework of broader aggregation and progress strategies.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the impact of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline on the gas market in Central and Eastern Europe (2016/2703(RSP)).

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is my pleasure to be here to address with honourable Members the issue of the Nord Stream 2 project and the impact it may have on central and eastern European Member States. Nord Stream 2 is a subject of huge concern for many Members in this House, but also for Member States and in particular for the central and eastern European Member States, as was reflected in the letter of nine prime ministers and leaders addressed to President Juncker on 17 March.  The concerns are of various natures, be they legal, geopolitical or economic. As regards the legal aspect, let me reiterate what we stated in this House some weeks ago. If built, Nord Stream 2 will have to fully comply, just like any other infrastructure project, with applicable European Union law, including on energy and environment.  The construction of such an important infrastructure project as Nord Stream 2 cannot happen in a legal void. This would also run counter to the interests of economic operators in having legal certainty. Nor can it be exclusively operated only according to Russian law. Against the background of colliding legal regimes, Nord Stream 2, if built, has to be operated under a legal framework which also takes due account of the key principles of our energy market rules. While respect for these legal principles is in our view a necessary precondition, we also recognise that for the central and eastern European Member States the issues of the impact on the security of supply of the region and on the central and eastern European gas market are of particular importance. Let me remind you that most of the central and eastern European gas market remains highly dependent on a dominant gas supplier, namely Gazprom, as well as on a limited number of transport corridors.  In the last few years, the Commission’s most important objective with regard to the central and eastern European Member States has been to foster progress in making the gas market more secure, competitive and diversified, thanks to the European Union’s internal energy market infrastructure, development and competition enforcement. In this context, let me mention the Commission’s energy security strategy of May 2014, supported by European Union Member States and this Parliament, and the security of supply package originally proposed, with legislative proposals aimed at improving the security of supply of the European Union and in particular the more vulnerable regions. Regarding infrastructure development, the Commission has provided strong support to the central and eastern European Member States in terms of improving their connectivity across markets through regional groupings such as BEMIP and CESEC, improving access to LNG through building of new LNG terminals in Lithuania and Poland, while another important terminal is planned in Croatia, and promoting the development of liquid gas HAPs not only in the Mediterranean , but also in Bulgaria. We will continue our efforts together with Member States to ensure that other key diversification projects are also completed in the coming years. Nord Stream 2 will, due to its route, alter the landscape of the European Union’s gas markets, and we will have to carefully assess its impact on our own priorities in terms of security of supply, diversification and creation of competitive gas markets, including in central and eastern Europe.  Clearly, Nord Stream 2 will not give access to a new source of supply or of a supplier and further increase excess capacity from Russia to the European Union. As regards transit rules, Nord Stream 2 could lead to gas transportation corridors being decreased from three to at least two – abandoning the route through Ukraine – and the German route via Poland could also be in danger. Such a reduction of routes would not improve security of supply.  Regarding the market impact of the Nord Stream 2 project, we are carefully analysing what impact it can have on competition on our gas markets, including in central and eastern Europe. We have made a lot of progress in implementing the Third Energy Package across Europe and we have to make sure that no market operator is able to leverage its dominant position to the detriment of consumers.  Let me say at the end of my statement a few words on Ukraine. Despite economic and political challenges, Ukraine continues to be a reliable gas partner and transit country. It is in the interests of all parties, including and notably the central and eastern European countries, that Ukraine remains a significant gas transit corridor. The successful implementation of the gas winter package, with the constructive engagement of both Russia and Ukraine and facilitated by the Commission, has helped to secure domestic consumption in Ukraine and contributed to a smooth transit in supply of Russian gas to the European Union. The Commission stands ready to continue this successfully proven format and to enlarge the trilateral talks to the negotiation of a new transit contract with Russia and Ukraine as the current one comes to an end in 2019.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Thank you, Commissioner, for a very important statement. Today is 9 May, Europe Day, a celebration of unity, understanding and cooperation. It is good that we are talking about Nord Stream II. There can be no doubt – this is apparent from all the discussions – that this project undermines European unity and solidarity, undermines trust and creates tensions between countries. Political reservations about this project also create investment uncertainty for business. As rapporteur for the Security of Gas Supply Regulation, I stress, like the Commissioner, that Nord Stream II strengthens the monopolistic position of a single supplier, challenges the principle of diversification of supply, and threatens the security of several central European countries. As such, it concerns the whole Union, not just a few countries. There are environmental concerns, including reservations about the development of the maritime economy in the Baltic Sea and commitments to Ukraine. This project should therefore not receive any support from the European Union and should be subject without exception to Eu law. In this context, I would like to ask the Commissioner and the European Commission whether, in line with the Conclusions of the European Council of December 2015, has the Commission formally requested the German authorities to apply the Third Energy Package to Nord Stream II?

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say on behalf of the Group of the Progressive Democrats in the European Parliament that I am in favour of creating energy infrastructures such as improving external supply and of finding expansive solutions to energy equipment that will make it possible to better modulate supply and costs in Europe.  There is no doubt that we need more instruments, more infrastructure to respond more flexibly to market developments and energy consumption. However, it seems clear to me – and I agree with the things we have heard from President Buzek – that the project to double the Nord Stream gas pipeline is not going in this direction and represents a step backwards in relation to the ambitions for coordinating energy policies that the European Commission drew up just a few months ago, in February 2015, in its communication on the Energy Union, and which this Parliament amended and signed in its resolution of 15 December.  What are the elements? Firstly, Nord Stream increases its energy dependence on a single supplier, namely the Russian giant Gazprom, and creates the conditions for the exercise of a dominant position in the market. At the moment there is no need to double the Nord Stream, as the current Nord Stream 1 exercises below its capabilities. In addition, Nord Stream 2 involves almost exclusively actors from a single Member State. In other words, it is a project for the use and consumption of only certain national interests and not of the general interests of the European Union. Finally, it is a vulnus in the definition of the future European energy architecture because it is a precedent, according to which a Member State has completely free hands in deciding on the energy strategy that must involve all European countries.  It is therefore not ideological reasons why they are and are opposed to them, but reasons for a specific policy that Europe has set out to political.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Nord Stream construction project is a test for the European Union. Its implementation, if indeed it were to happen, would show that all these beautiful words about Europe spoken in this House have little to do with reality when it comes to the powerful but particular political and economic interests of some countries and businesses. Who can believe the assurances of the consortium planning Nord Stream that this project is purely commercial and not political, since we know very well that Russia is using gas as a political weapon to achieve its neo-imperial objectives, since we know that the capacity of existing gas pipelines to transport gas from Russia to the EU already far exceeds the Union's demand for Russian gas. This project would deepen the dependence of EU countries on Russia, and already more than a third of the gas imported by the Union comes from that country. Five Member States depend on Russia as the only external supplier of all imported gas. This investment would further deepen the divide between eastern and western Europe, and would allow Russia to easily bypass Ukraine as a transit country to the European Union, depriving Ukraine of around two billion dollars a year in transit revenue, which would perhaps destabilise Ukraine.  Yet we have devoted so many words to the democratic and economic development of this country.  The Commission acknowledges that the nord stram 2 project is economically unjustified and that it is contrary to the Union's energy objectives such as increased security of supply or diversification. So how does the Commission intend to counteract these potential negative effects? It is also clear that a gas pipeline passing through territories governed by Union law should also be subject to this law in the subsea part. Will the Commission – and I will repeat professor Buzek's question here – formally ask the German authorities on the application of the third energy package to Nord Stream 2?

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, by the end of this year we will have laid down the tracks for the European energy union. These are exciting and ambitious times as the energy union is one of the biggest and most important projects in the history of the European Union. We have to deliver. Why is it that we are creating this energy union? To create a well—functioning energy market, to attract capital, to create growth and jobs, to push the sustainable transition agenda much further – and, not least, to be less dependent on Russian gas and supplies from Mr Putin.  This leads me to the obvious question: where does Nord Stream 2 fit into this context? To me the simple answer is that it does not fit at all. I am fully aware of the fact that we will be dependent, to some degree, on Russian gas in years to come, but bear in mind that Nord Stream 1 is operating at around only half of its capacity today. Therefore I find it very hard to identify any economic, environmental or political arguments for Nord Stream 2. I find it very hard to see any positive perspectives for anyone other than Mr Putin in this.  So far, I do not think that either we, the European Parliament, or the Member States have taken Nord Stream 2 and the perspectives of this project seriously enough. More than anything, we need to conduct a firm geopolitical study on North Stream 2 and the implications of the project. We need the Commission to step up its efforts, ensuring that Nord Stream 2 complies with all our laws and intentions. If not, we risk putting the entire energy union in jeopardy, and that would be a total disaster.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Ladies and gentlemen, we are constantly discussing the issue of Northern Pipeline II, and we hear the same concerns expressed repeatedly. In reality, however, not only is the Northern Pipeline not a problem, but it comes in response to the Union itself's inability to achieve energy efficiency and supply while enhancing its energy security. The problem for us is that the European Union has not yet achieved its objective of diversifying sources and supply routes. The problem is that no substantive measures have yet been taken to remove the energy isolation in which many States and regions of the Union are doomed, particularly in the South and not in the North. The problem is that we have not yet been able to tackle the serious problems in energy supply while energy poverty is a major problem for a large proportion of citizens. What is needed is to make immediate use of the Union's domestic energy sources, to stop ignoring the role of deposits discovered in Cyprus, which is a Member State, but also of deposits in the wider Eastern Mediterranean and North Africa region. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to directly support energy investment in the Eastern Mediterranean, to promote the creation of a Mediterranean gas hub with pipelines and also with the development of liquefied natural gas production. Equally important for us is to develop an integrated strategy for the development of renewable energy sources, while ensuring affordable prices for consumers. name: Tibor SZANYI

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), 'blue card' reply. – That is precisely what I have noted is that because important issues of its energy security have not yet been resolved in the European Union, new infrastructure is being created and one of them is The Northern Pipeline II. I would like to focus more attention on the fact that the European Union must turn to domestic energy sources but, at the same time, develop renewable energy even further.

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to refer to the visions that the Commission, in particular, has set out in its work to highlight the Energy Union as one of the major tasks of this parliamentary term; to have a real change, that we can create more common energy markets in Europe, to increase self-sufficiency and production of energy, to bring about a rapprochement with the climate targets by investing more in our own energy, renewable energy, rather than the great dependence on imports that Europe has towards the rest of the world, and not least from Russia, which we are discussing now. I think these visions are very important. It provides a basis for strengthening Europe as part of the world and strengthening our competitiveness, and also creates many more jobs in the future, but also for the long-term lower energy prices. The problem with this investment that we are talking about [...], it is that this will go directly against almost every point in the vision that we are talking about for the Energy Union. When you look at it from that point of view, it becomes unreasonable to make efforts, such as one day talking about us doing something together, creating sustainable development with less CO2 emissions, and also less vulnerability, but the next day we are doing the opposite. I think that the Commission must be even stronger, but I thank Mr Cañete for saying that the laws and rules that we have decided here must, of course, apply to this project as well. I would therefore also like to continue the rolling point that has been sent around here with regard to the third energy package from Mr Buzeck, chairman of the Committee on Industry and Energy, that if we in Europe really want to comply with the rules we have set out in the third energy package, then it may be unreasonable, impossible that they can be compatible with this package, because Nord Stream 2 means a supplier that has complete control over the entire infrastructure. I think it must be remembered that, over the last thirty or forty years, Russia has used energy as a political weapon more than any other country, and it is Gazprom that is the main player in that game.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Caete, I would like to thank commissioner for his work We have now heard many important points from the previous speakers, including very critical points, as to why this Nord Stream 2 project should not be implemented, and these points must be taken seriously! This goes from a lack of diversification to the point where the European Union should not support this project. However, I would like to comment on a number of points which should perhaps be taken seriously. The first point is that let us look at the consortium that is carrying this major project. This is a consortium of a European dimension. This is not only Gazprom, but two German companies, Uniper and BASF Wintershall Holding, that is Shell, that is ANGI and that is the Austrian OMV – is a quite respectable group.  The second issue is European security of supply: Nord Stream 2 could double the capacity of the two existing strands by 55 to a total of 110 billion cubic metres of gas. It could supply gas to 52 million households in Europe and secure a third of Europe's gas needs. It is up to us, ladies and gentlemen, when we are talking about diversification, to develop the south-eastern corridor in the south-eastern Mediterranean – as a previous speaker has already mentioned today – and to ensure greater diversification.  Infrastructure spending: You mentioned recently, Commissioner Caete, last week, that Europe has an investment gap in the energy sector of EUR 200 billion. Nord Stream 2 would bring in 9 billion euros in investment during a construction phase and another 7 billion for the expansion of additional pipeline capacities and additional routes. In addition, additional investments in equipment: the Austrian company Voestalpine alone has been awarded the contract to provide 300 000 tonnes of high-strength tubular sheets for this pipeline, at a time when we are discussing all the problems in the steel industry.  My own country, Austria, supports this project not only because the OMV is represented, the Baumgarten node is essential and voest can make an important contribution. However, the above concerns must be addressed, namely with regard to Ukraine as a gas transit country and the modernisation of the Ukrainian gas pipeline infrastructure, as well as with regard to the compatibility of Nord Stream 2 with EU law, in particular the question of the territorial application of the third internal energy market package.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The way the European Commission relates to the Nord Stream 2 pipeline, compared with South Stream, is a typical case of double standards. The construction of South Stream would have provided an alternative route bypassing Ukraine for several European and Central European countries, but there were objections: they were based on competition law, bureaucratic, liberal principles, until the result was that this had failed. Commissioner Cañete replied to my written question that the problem with South Stream was that it would only diversify the route. What about Nord Stream 2? Neither source diversifies nor route. Well, then why is it going to happen? Obviously, the big difference between, say, the joint action of the four Visegrad prime ministers and Angela Merkel. That's what you've decided. What these countries were not allowed to do is possible for Germany.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, my thanks to the Commissioner. Everyone tends to love rules and competition until we need to practise them. Then it gets tough, because it involves a lot of difficult issues. But I think it is quite clear that Nord Stream 2 has no real commercial logic on its own. It is not compatible with the principle and rules of unbundling, with the Third Energy Package. It is not – and I cannot see how it could be – compatible with the aims and the rules of the energy union. It will increase the dominance of Gazprom where it is dominant, it will strengthen its monopoly, and it is a part of Russian policy versus Europe. Commissioner, it is a difficult thing to deal with, but do you think it will make Europe more or less dependent on Russian gas?

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, Nord Stream 2 is both unnecessary, unwanted and dangerous: unnecessary because current capacity is nowhere near fully utilised; unwanted because we know that our central and eastern European Member States are worried about this plan for good reason; dangerous even, because it will only strengthen Mr Putin’s energy hold on Europe. Nord Stream 2 will bypass the Baltic States and allow Russia to completely deny Ukraine vital gas deliveries. The energy union should strengthen Europe, strengthen renewables, strengthen European cooperation on energy and lead us forward in a carbon-free future. Nord Stream 2 is the exact opposite of all of this. It divides Europe into two: those who will have and those who will not have access to Russian gas. I say that Europe in its entirety should say ‘No’ to becoming even more dependent on Russian gas and that is why the Commission must state clearly to Russia, to Germany, to Denmark and to all others that Nord Stream 2 is an unwanted, unneeded and unsafe project that belongs not at the bottom of the Baltic Sea but at the bottom of a wastepaper basket , clearly stamped ‘rejected’.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which A great deal of the right things have been said here, which speak against the Nord Stream 2 project, and also a number of things that speak for it. But I would like to draw attention to something else: the German Federal Government thinks that the Nord Stream 2 project is about the decision between private companies and that politicians should stay out of it. Since they are part of the government in Germany, I ask the members of the SPD in this House this. Firstly, your then Chancellor Schroeder concluded with Gazprom shortly before the 2005 Bundestag election. Was this not political interference? Second, shortly after the lost election, Schroeder was appointed chairman of Gazprom's supervisory board by Putin. My question is this: would you not also regard this as an act of passive and active bribery? And thirdly, for Schroeder, Putin is still a pure democrat today, and I would like to ask the Social Democrats in this House: do you think that his mandate at Gazprom 1 might have something to do with it? Nord Stream 2 was a wrong decision, politically motivated. Here we have the opportunity to correct a wrong decision politically. We will not be able to agree to Nord Stream 2.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, the Commission has made a number of important innovations in the direction of the European energy union. I think that this House backs this initiative, at least in its majority. Yet we have a project whose implications you have described, and I do appreciate that many of those that you have described were in fact of a negative nature. There are clearly down sides; the Commission acknowledges that. In other words, we have a project which is clearly not heading in the direction of the energy union, but which – even worse – is splitting the European Union apart. So we are already fragmenting the unity that we need in order to be able to back the energy union before we have even started to dwell on concrete legislative proposals. For me, this is further confirmation that, apart from all the economic arguments – or the lack thereof, as has been mentioned by my colleagues – this is welcome news to the Kremlin, because the Kremlin is part of a deal which is splitting the European Union apart. The implications are very concrete. You have mentioned the downsides, and you were more explicit than ever before, but from here on we need to embark on a clear-cut strong position. What will happen when Nord Stream 3, or any other project, comes around?  I will stop here – and I apologise as I have to leave for another meeting, which I am late for – but I am sure that my colleagues will take care of this and that the Commission will reply to a number of the questions which we jointly share.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: – Mr President, the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline is a practical example of how the European Union often acts contrary to its earlier intentions. When the gas crisis erupted a few years ago, EU politicians agreed that ensuring safe gas supply was one of the Union's common priorities. Things are obviously different today. Nord Stream 2 can be judged from three viewing angles. The first is to secure sufficient gas for EU countries. The second is the political decision as to whether only one Member State can be so significantly represented at the entry of natural gas into the European Union. The third aspect is the economic aspect. Gas transit is an interesting source of funding for some countries, I understand that it is Ukraine, Poland, Slovakia, the Czech Republic. Personally, I prefer to secure enough gas, and therefore I see no reason to question this intention in any way. Finally, I would like to add that it is only through some strange behind-the-scenes machinations that a gas pipeline directly to the Balkans has not yet been built. It is in this case that it would be appropriate to discuss strengthening the security of supply of natural gas to EU countries.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: – Mr President, colleagues, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work There are complicated things, and there are quite simple things. The issue of the extension of the Nord Stream II gas pipelines is, in my view, entirely simple. We think about drugs and drug dependence. We all know that drug addiction is very dangerous and needs to get rid of it. As with drugs, the whole European Union depends on imported gas. We already have almost 70% of imports, with a tendency to increase further. Who is our largest gas supplier? It is the Russian export monopoly gazprom. There is now a plan for several European companies, together with Russia's Gazprom, to double the so-called Nord Stream pipeline in 2012-u2012 Nord Stream II\u2012\u2012 in this way. What would it do? This is because a drug addict has a prickling vein with twice the dose. It's life-threatening. This is dangerous for Europe. We cannot go this way. It is a matter of good times, as is the drug, and the medicine we have adopted is the course that the Commission has proposed and we have supported the so-called Energy Union.
