The principles of the Energy Union show us clearly and clearly that we must reduce our import dependence, we must differentise our energy sources and we cannot allow any kind of monopoly on the European market. This single market must be created. The Nord Stream II project goes against everything as such a dangerous drug. Commissioner, I call on you to be courageous and to do everything to prevent this project! Thank you for your attention!

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, alternative routes should be offered to enable Europe to have new supplies at a better price, with the implementation of new infrastructures that are part of the energy corridors. In a context of energy interdependence such as the current one, the lack of long-term strategic vision favors uncertainty in markets. The southern corridor, with the potential to cover up to 20% of the European Union's gas needs, must therefore be a priority. The European Union must be able to diversify its gas sources so that all regions have access to at least two different sources of supply. In this way, we will move forward in strengthening the Union's energy security, ensuring a stable supply and ensuring a stable long-term energy transit.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: – I would like to make a plea today for a critical but also realistic view of the Nordstream 2 project. Gas will be an important fuel in the energy transition to more green and more renewable energy sources. Gas is less polluting than, for example, coal or lignite, and it is also complementary to renewable energy to cope with the off-peak times. Gas is also more often used for heating in households and businesses. In other words, there is an increasing demand for gas and Nordstream 2 can meet a large part of that need. However, this should certainly not be an excuse for some major energy players to abuse their market position. It is also very important that the Energy Union continues to look for alternative sources of different origins. I therefore call on the Commission to ensure that competition rules are respected in the context of this project. In addition, Member States should also be encouraged to diversify into their energy suppliers.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Mr President, the worst thing about this debate is that we are not talking about access to energy, nor about climate change, but we are talking about pure and harsh geostrategia, conflicts over access to fossil fuels. Energy agreements with third countries directly condition the type of relationship we want to build with them. In this case, the German government, guided by the low price of Russian gas, prefers to go above the interests of the East countries. This project is an economic and environmental aberration. The different studies show a continuous drop in gas demand. The European Court of Auditors itself acknowledged that the Commission's gas demand forecasts are persistently overestimated, therefore it is by no means necessary to increase the gas supply capacity at present. However, there are German companies that invest in this project, as a result of leaving the energy future in the hands of the market. The 'no' to this project without justification, economic or climate, is essential, as is the Commission's intervention to stop it.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I hope that this debate will have practical significance, that is to say, it will have an impact on the European Commission's strategy and reach the companies involved. Today's European Union is in a lot of trouble, it needs unifying rather than disintegrating projects, it needs demonstrations such as the ones that took place on the streets of Warsaw last Saturday. The Nord Stream 2 project, on the other hand, is a factor of disintegration. The more people are emaculate in economic issues, the more they see that it is not a commercial project. The more he looks at geopolitical considerations or the meaning of the Energy Union, the more he sees a contradiction between the principles of diversification and independence from a monopolistic supplier and the Nord Stream 2 project. Therefore, without prolonging this debate, I hope that the European Commission will free us from this problem and then we will be able to address other challenges that are not lacking in the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, by doubling the capacity of the North Stream pipeline, the North Stream II project will allow imports of cheap Russian gas to increase on the European market, and this is economically positive. Unfortunately, however, the current rules on the operation of natural gas in Europe will not allow this capacity to be fully exploited for reasons of 'alleged' competition. The third-party forced access rule renders almost 50% of The Roth Stream I's capacity almost useless, just like The Orth Stream II. As you can see, these restrictions jeopardise the economic viability of costly pipeline projects, especially in times of low prices such as the one we are going through. At the same time, the Commission must ensure that all Member States, not just Germany, have the same capacity to carry out the construction of energy infrastructure, at least from a legal point of view. It must not judge pipeline plans by double standards. The ideological policies imposed by the Commission under the third energy package already cost south stream cancellation in 2014. On the other hand, Roth Stream I received, in particular because of Germany, exceptions which allowed it to be completed. We hope that the Commission will not create obstacles in the future with regard to the TAP pipeline, the ITGI pipeline and other projects that may be developed in the Balkans. It is now imperative to create in Greece an energy hub that offers security and growth prospects throughout south-eastern Europe.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Mr President, Europe is talking about energy union and energy security. There is a lot of talk, it is not put into practice at the same level. The best example is Connecting Europe Facility: energy funds have been reduced by more than 50%. Energy security without resource security does not exist. The security of resources without diversification cannot be achieved. Nord Stream does not fall under any security rule, either as a source, which has proved unpredictable, politicized and conditioned, nor as a market rule, causing a dangerous dependence on a single source. Gazprom's attempt to increase Europe's dependence on Russian gas, South Stream, Turkish Stream, Nord Stream is evident. It is incomprehensible that Europe's passivity relative to the attempts at diversification in the southern corridor. Active, financial, political involvement is needed to supply the European Union with gas from the south-east from existing or new sources: Azerbaijan, Iran, the Black Sea, the Mediterranean. Involvement on the ground, not just in debates.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. All those gathered here, representing both the European Parliament and the European Commission, are aware that this project is not only an economic project, but above all a political one that is striking at the energy security of many european Union countries, including Polish. According to the latest forecasts, there is no significant increase in natural gas demand in the European Union as a whole in the coming years – in which case the expansion of Russian transmission infrastructure certainly has no economic justification. This is confirmed by the fact that the cost of building further strands is estimated at around EUR 10 billion, while the estimated costs of upgrading transmission infrastructure in Ukraine are half as low.  In addition, Nord Stream 2 prevents the development of the port of Świnoujście, which has already been mentioned very often and which is a political issue at the moment. Negative arguments or proposals have already been presented several times during meetings and debates in Parliament and the Commission. However, further questions remain, including how does the Commission intend to support projects that bring real diversification or eliminate bottlenecks within the European Union? Because these are real needs when it comes to energy infrastructure in the European Union, as opposed to Russia's additional capacity.  A few weeks ago, during a debate in the European Parliament, Commissioner Šefčovič suggested signing the Germany-Russia international agreement governing the legal status of Nord Stream 2. How does the German Government relate to this proposal? What are the arguments used by the European Commission to convince Germany to do so? Does the Nord Stream thread appear in discussions with partners outside the European Union, such as the US? What is the position of our key US partners on this issue and will it be taken into account by the European Commission?

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Mr President! Europe needs to make itself less dependent on gas from Putin's Russia. Unfortunately, the so-called Nord Stream 2 project is pulling in the exact opposite direction. The project is bad for Europe, and then I fully agree with my colleague Buzek, who said in his speech that it should under no circumstances have EU funds in grants.  Is the project at all in line with the energy union objective? I doubt very much! We should also look at the so-called IGA agreements, just as they should be at the Council meeting now on 6 June. This project on Nord Stream, how is it related to the IGA agreements? After all, we must make ourselves less dependent on external energy.  It is a question for me also of security of supply, but it is also a question of security policy. We must place more emphasis on other energy sources, such as solar and wind, while at the same time using the energy we have in Europe more efficiently. Energy efficiency and renewable energy are better than handing the money into Putin's treasury.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. This information has already been in this Chamber, but I will remind you of it for the sake of order. The existing gas infrastructure allows nearly 250 billion m3 of gas to be transferred from Russia to Europe, while eu gas imports from Russia amounted to around 120 billion m3 in 2014 , i.e. only an incomplete 50% of the transmission capacity.  Secondly, the level of use of existing LNG infrastructure – liquefied gas – was only 25% in the Union in 2014. This means that as much as 75% of this infrastructure is unused, which in absolute terms amounts to 150 billion m3 of gas, which is significantly more than the Union imports from Russia.  Thirdly, after the first two Nord Stream pipelines were put into operation, the capacity utilities of gas pipelines passing through Ukrainian territory fell sharply in 2014 from 58% to 28%, while the use of the first two Nord Stream strands has increased from 36% to 60%, which means that nord stream 2's main objective will be to increase Russian capacity, thus completely eliminating gas transmission through Ukraine and making it difficult or even cutting off Russian gas for Slovakia and other central and eastern European countries.  Finally, I have the question: in the Commission's view, should the Commission not be more firm on this proposal? (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Nord Stream 2 is a political project, so I wanted to point out that Professor Kuźmiuk said that Ukraine gets two billion a year from this, that the cost of putting it is ten billion, but after all, Poland or Slovakia also take money. Not paying Ukraine two billion a year perhaps has some economic justification, right? On the other hand, I am surprised that no one is talking – although this is an important question – about the country most threatened by Nord Stream 2, Belarus.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – There is no doubt that transit countries, when charging for gas transmission, make money from this, but since we are in one body of the European Union, European solidarity should be based on the fact that the interests of the Member States are taken into account above all. I would remind you that Ukraine is an associated country, so we should indeed, on the basis of European solidarity, keep an eye on these interests. Nord Stream 2 clearly undermines these interests and that should guide us in opposing this investment.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, Europe's great dependence on Russian energy is a problem for Europe. In particular, risks have increased since Putin's Russia has taken energy as its foreign policy weapons and part of its power policy. We know that more than a third of Europe's energy comes from Russia, and it is natural gas, which accounts for up to around 40%, that is most dependent. All the objectives that are now being made to promote the Energy Union – increasing self-sufficiency, improving markets, diversifying energy sources and better connecting European countries – are all important and worth supporting. But Nord Stream 2 is not compatible with these goals. That goes against the objectives of the Energy Union. More than 20 speeches have been made here, from all the political groups, and no one has said that this is a good and worth supporting project. Nord Stream 2 does not deserve the support of the European Union.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I am not going to repeat things that you know very well. The data concerning this project have been in its possession for some time and he has also commented on them very explicitly.  Anyone in Europe and throughout the world who is familiar with energy issues and the European Union smiles when this project evolves, because if we were to sit down and try to create an example of a school, which would be able to contradict at a moment's time all the objectives that the European Union is setting itself in the field of energy. , we wouldn't find a fitting example like this.  So the first issue is: let us do credit to the European Union and let us not show that we are so contradictory. Secondly, let us take into account the fact that, if a project like this were to be carried out, there would be a whole section of Europe that would not be able to take advantage of the gas that will arrive in Europe from Russia through this pipeline, because there are not enough connections. So it's political nonsense and it's economic nonsense, so help us not to be ridiculed and block this project with us.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In the absence of time, I will omi point out the economic thread – this has already been mentioned, there is no economic justification. I will also omilyt the question of the legality and compatibility of this project with European Union law, international law, environmental law, etc. – because even if investors meet the required rules, it is still a bad project because it undermines the idea and the most important principles of the European Union, including the Energy Union. This is a project that undermines security of supply. This is a project that violates the principle of diversification, including the principle of diversification of sources, suppliers and supply routes. This is a project that violates the principle of competitiveness. Finally, most importantly, this is a project that violates the principle of solidarity and trust. What do we need today in the difficult times of the European Union more than just solidarity and mutual trust?

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Today's debate clearly shows how controversial and complex nord stream 2 is. It goes far beyond not only Central and Eastern Europe itself, but also strictly energy issues. I think we may be tempted to say that it focuses, as in the lens, on what condition the European Union is in today. It will show whether we are able to work jointly and severally for the interests of Europe as a whole, show how resilient we are to external factors, including the 'divide and rule' strategy, and will finally show how seriously we take the previously adopted principles seriously. I therefore very much support the European Commission, within the framework of its competence, to thoroughly check this project in terms of compliance with both the objectives of the Energy Union and European law. I am convinced that if this analysis is reliable, the result will be unequivocal for Nord Stream 2 – negative.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, we should first of all have in mind the context. Russia is not a normal partner any more. Its strategic aim is to weaken the EU – to split and discredit it. Gazprom has been, and is still, the main tool of Russian foreign policy. At a time of Russia’s increasing provocations, the Kremlin tries to demonstrate that the EU still needs it; that we can be further disorientated, that they can make fun of our energy union, and that they can weaken and economically isolate Ukraine. In this new situation, I am afraid there is no room for pretending that we can conduct two parallel policies – one of Russian sanctions, and another pretending that this is private business. Nord Stream 2 is a politically motivated project. We cannot hide our heads in the sand. It has to be countered by strong and clear political means.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I am convinced that Nord Stream 2 does not comply with the objectives of the Energy Union, nor with our climate ambitions, nor with the EU's objective of diversifying energy producers. So the question is why we allow this gas pipeline to be built. The simple answer is that the EU Member States do not trust each other when it comes to energy supply, and in the absence of this trust, we allow Russia to play off the Member States against each other. But the fact is that if nord stream is to be departed, it will reduce security of supply in Central and Eastern Europe in particular. It will give more strength to Russia to squeeze out individual countries with the help of energy. It will increase gazprom's and Russia's dominant position, reduce the diversity of suppliers, put Ukraine and surrounding countries in a difficult position and destroy climate ambitions. Is it not better, then, to try to build trust between our countries than to allow this project to continue? At a time when security in our area, particularly in Central and Eastern Europe, is worse than it has been for a very long time, it is foolhardy to go ahead with the plans for Nord Stream 2. I'm just saying, stop the plans for Nord Stream 2 as soon as possible.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Madam President, I am pleased that tonight we have given one big and agree not to the North Stream 2 project, because our goal is not to help diversify supply rates from Russia but to diversify energy sources in Europe and reduce dependence on imports. Energy dependency is very easy to turn into economic, economic into social and so we are pushing Europe, which we want to make a leader and driver of development, with the North Flow 2 project in the other direction. There is something else I would like to point out: the European Commission has identified 195 key energy infrastructure projects. These are projects that will contribute to meeting the strategic objectives of the Energy Union, and with this North Flow 2 project we are putting under question the value and implementation of these energy projects, the preparation of which we have already started to finance from the CEF. We don't want that at all.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, it is necessary but futile to recall that the unity of the Union is being broken by Germany and will soon collapse, not only because of the possible Brexit, illegal immigrants, austerity policies and the strangulation of Greece, which are policies imposed by Germany. It will collapse because it is now clear that more and more countries are openly resisting the policies most of which are being blackmailed: Roth Stream II is of exclusive interest to Germany, which is indifferent to the reactions of other states, such as Poland and Italy. Germany pursues a two-and-a-kind policy, prohibiting other countries from having privileged economic relations with Russia, while it benefits the most from them, against ethical and political norms. Germany has played a major role in its silence and tolerance of the Ukrainian crisis, drawing other Member States. It is now even using the Ukrainian crisis as an excuse to force the ratification of an agreement with Gazprom. At the same time, however, it prevents the construction of South Stream that would transport Russian natural gas through Greece, Bulgaria and Italy. I am not a prophet to guess when the Union will collapse, but I believe that division is inevitable as long as we tolerate Germany's insatiable thirst for political and economic dominance.

name: András GYÜRK
text: – Madam President, for the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, the expansion of Nord Stream does not mean diversification or an improvement in their competitiveness. Moreover, if the project is carried out, on the gas pipeline interconnector that we have built together to better connect fragmented Central and Eastern Europe to the much more liquid gas market in Western Europe, Russian gas will be imported. Thus, it is doubtful whether there will be capacity on the connectors for alternative deliveries.  This will be a step backwards in terms of the diversification objective set. Central and Eastern European countries are not expected to benefit economically either, as multi-country transport can significantly increase the price of energy. I call on the European Commission to strive to achieve the Energy Union goals and to enforce EU legislation, in particular the third energy package. This is in the interest of European citizens.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – I will probably say something dissonant in this debate. Nordstream 1 was started at a time when relations between Europe and Russia were good and promising. In this atmosphere, the South Current project was born, from which we departed. I believe that the Commission and those who will lead the energy union should be trusted to be able to strike a balance between economic reasons, between environmental reasons, on the one hand, and geostratetic reasons on the other. However, I think it is too tempting to talk about Europe's energy perspective only under the influence of geo-strategy. I think we're smart enough to know how to run accounts for other elements.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the honourable Members for their contributions to this debate that have enlightened the views of the Commission on this very difficult issue. Let me say from the very beginning that I heard some honourable Members stressing that we were discussing gas too much and we should concentrate on other sources of energy. It is clear that after the Paris agreement on climate change, we are on a path of decarbonising our economies and developing renewables and energy efficiency, but it is also clear that it will take some time. In the meanwhile the cleanest fossil fuel is gas and we have to ensure security of supply for the 28 Member States of the European Union – not for a single Member State but for the 28 Member States of the European Union.  That is why the Commission is implementing a security of supply policy, trying to diversify sources, suppliers and routes. That is why we have come along with an LNG gas strategy on one side and that is why we are developing interconnectors in central and south-eastern Europe, that is why we have implemented reverse flows and that is why the Commission is supporting the Southern Corridor, which is another alternative source of supply. So the Commission will keep on applying these policies which are the ones needed to assure security supply all over the European Union. There were two specific clear questions. One was by Mr Hökmark who asked whether this project would make us more or less dependent on Russian gas. The answer is very clear, and you know it already, because we speak of about 100 bcm going through a single corridor. That would mean 26% of all European Union gas consumption and 80% of Russian gas imports on a single route. The answer is very clear. Due to the size, the route and the strategic character, it would probably change the architecture of today’s European gas market and further increase the dominance of Gazprom in the western European gas market.  The European Union has made a lot of progress in opening up and integrating energy markets. That is why the European Union should therefore make sure that no market operator is able to leverage its dominant position to the detriment of competitors and consumers. So it is clear that this may change. It is also clear that we have to review those changes and apply European laws. European laws must be applied in all aspects. I come back to Mr Buzek’s questions. He asked whether we were in contact with the German authorities. I can say that, following the mandate of the European Council, we have made contact with the German authorities on all levels and my services are in contact with the German regulators to have a complete picture of all the facts needed to assess the project. This is a complex project – it has an onshore part which touches the waters of five different Member States – and is difficult to evaluate.  But what I can say is that in the Commission we are convinced that European Union law needs to be applied, including the principles of energy law, which also need to be applied in the case of the offshore part. We will continue our discussions with the German authorities on what this entails in practice.  But beyond the application of the legal framework this project has very clear geopolitical consequences and all the Members who have intervened have pointed out those consequences. Thus this also needs to be discussed at a political level and that is why both Vice—President Šefčovič and I have explained exactly the same political concerns to the German Government on several occasions. What I can say in conclusion is that we all agree that energy produced in the European Union must be fully aligned with European Union core policy objectives, including energy security. We cannot look in an isolated way at infrastructure projects. We have to find comprehensive and well—balanced solutions which benefit all Member States alike, as well as our neighbours. So the Commission will take very seriously the remarks of the honourable Members. We will continue monitoring this process and applying European Union legislation. There was another question at the end on whether we have the opinion of the United States. We have the opinion, we hear the honourable Members, but I must say that just last Wednesday we had the Energy Council with the United States and we also discussed this topic, because it is a problem of geopolitical importance and is worth discussing in our bilateral relations with the United States.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – The energy union’s aim is providing mutual benefits: to secure energy for consumers at affordable prices, create competitive market opportunities for suppliers and strengthen EU members’ solidarity. One of the Union’s key goals was achieving greater energy diversification by finding alternative sources. Nord Stream 2 represents neither source nor supply diversification. It duplicates the existing Nord Stream 1 pipeline and can become a Russian political weapon.  In order to stay resilient, the EU needs more cooperativeness and interconnection. This killer-project’s aim is opening up old divisions by destroying recently installed interconnectors in central Europe and by creating winners that will be directly supplied by Nord Stream 2 and losers bypassed by it. Ukraine’s European future would also be put at risk as Nord Stream 2 would create the conditions to cut off the gas currently transited through it.  Developing alternative energy sources infrastructure, boosting EU energy production and building new pipelines and interconnections compose an investment plan towards a common and secure energy future. Energy security is a key pillar of the EU’s energy union strategy and I believe Nord Stream 2 would eliminate any prospect of achieving a competitive and resilient internal EU gas market, free from political manipulation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. The Nord Stream 2 project, managed by the Russian gas company Gazprom, goes against the objectives of the Energy Union and undermines solidarity between Member States. At the moment this project is not necessary considering that Nord Stream 1 works below its capabilities. With Nord Stream 2, the Russian giant Gazprom would have practically full control of an important part of the gas distribution and storage system in Central Europe, taking over shares of deposits in the North Sea and bypassing or cutting off not only Ukraine, but several central and eastern European countries. There are also legal and environmental concerns. The project is not economically justified and would have negative consequences for the marine environment of the Baltic Sea. Nord Stream 2 also operates only on the basis of Russia's laws and does not comply with European energy and environmental standards. I therefore call on the Commission to put an end to the Nord Stream 2 project as soon as possible and to focus on South Stream, which is the real long-term solution for providing energy to European citizens.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – The need for Nord Stream 2 also calls into question the common climate and energy policy objectives, the cop21 objectives and the principle of diversification of energy supply. The project also raises concerns about its impact on both energy security and the diversification of energy supply. In addition to policy concerns, I would like to draw attention to an obvious double standard: in 2014, the European Commission claimed that Gazprom's business practices on the central and eastern European gas market constituted an abuse of market dominance and violated EU antitrust rules. It also had the construction of South Stream shut down, citing the third energy package. This position was appropriate from both an energy policy and a security policy perspective. However, now that Germany wants to build a pipeline, Gazprom suddenly appears as a reliable operator and, by reference to the specific rules on undersea pipelines, the Commission may even consider the proposed gas pipeline to be in line with the third energy package.  Strictly legally, this can be the case, but it must be seen that the authorisation of a project that also has an impact on the gas market in the CENTRAL AND EASTERN EUROPEAN region will also have a fundamental impact on the region's relationship with the Union, as it will be considered by the Member States as a double standard, not without reason. In the countries of the region, which are already in conflict with the Union, this will have consequences for the perception of European integration as a whole.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – Beyond the undeniable negative effects, which for marine ecosystems will have the construction of a new gas pipeline in the Baltic to rejoin Russia and Germany, and beyond the geopolitical circumstances of Ukraine, this facility is by no means necessary: It does not improve security of supply, as there are several gas pipelines that fulfill this function; It would give a dominant position to a single supplying undertaking, and to a single Member State. Moreover, russia's already high transport capacity would increase without justification. Currently, only about 50% of Russia's transport capacity is used and the available capacity far exceeds the EU's needs. It would jeopardize routes through Romania and Bulgaria, adversely affecting the diversification of supply to the EU. All this creates serious doubts about the project's compatibility with the internal energy market, in particular the third energy package. Natural gas can be a backup fuel, in transit to a new energy model based on the use of renewables, but under no circumstances should it be a replacement fuel. Increasing supply capacity would delay the entry of clean energy into Europe.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – I believe that the Nord Stream 2 project needs to be analysed from three points of view. In view of legality and compliance with existing European legislation, namely the EU Energy Security Strategy adopted in May 2014, it is necessary to ensure that European legislation is respected and applied in all segments of the Nord Stream 2 project and that it is not against the objectives of the Energy Union. As regards trade and capacity-enhancing arguments, Nord Stream 2 disadvantages the Central and Eastern European states. , Nord Stream 2 must contribute to the objective of diversification, not dependence on a supplier.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: in writing. – Interestingly, on Europe Day, while celebrating the European continent’s unity, we are confronted with a project that divides Europe. Contrary to some opinions, the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline is not a commercial venture – it is a purely political project hampering mutual trust in Europe and weakening our energy security.  Firstly, with the existing pipeline only being used up to about 70% of its capacity, building of a new leg is economically unjustified. Secondly, it might have an economic justification only if Russia decided to stop the transit through Ukraine, thus using gas supplies as a tool of political pressure. We all know that Gazprom is not a typical business company – it is a foreign policy instrument of the Russian Government.  Moreover, Nord Stream 2 would violate the key principle of the energy union – diversifying sources of energy. In 2013, 39% of all natural gas imports to the EU were from Russia, with several countries being fully dependent on imports from Russia. The debate on Nord Stream 2 shows that some Member States only pay lip service to values such as solidarity and security. This must change if we want to show European citizens that the EU is still a legitimate project.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – There have already been dozens of studies on Europe's need to diversify energy suppliers for their own safety. The implementation of the third energy package has fundamentally changed the situation in Lithuania – even a few years ago we were 100% dependent on Gazprom gas, and today we are talking about real plans to completely abandon them. The possibility of choosing rather than accepting the conditions of an increasingly aggressive foreign policy russia is an aspiration of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. The European Commission has taken the right steps towards the establishment of the Energy Union. However, the plan to build Nord Stream 2 is completely contrary to this objective. Naturally, the EU's largest economy is striving to maximise its efficiency, and it is said that the agreement will allow this to happen. However, the recent debate in the Bundestag as to how much this 'commercial' project will cost Germany, which will need to adapt its domestic gas networks to a new stream, raises serious doubts. The initial estimates amount to around EUR 500 million. Euro. It is clear that the implementation of the project will also cost the rest of the country a lot, with Europe paying a huge amount for an even greater dependence on Russian gas. The damage to Nord Stream 2 can therefore be talked about not only from geopolitical or energy security, but also from a cost-effective point of view. All the more so, the soon-to-be-opened possibility of importing gas from the US can fundamentally change the European gas market. Trade with this strategic partner, rather than an aggressive neighbour, should be the direction in which it is going.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – There is no doubt that the planned construction of Nord Stream 2 undermines energy security, but also other vital interests of central and eastern European countries.  Firstly, once the second strand of the Nord Stream gas pipeline has been built, these countries can be cut off at any time – for political reasons, for example – from Russian gas, on which they are still heavily dependent. Russia will be able to send gas to its strategic market, i.e. western Europe, without Ukraine.  Secondly, if this controversial investment is implemented, the countries of the region could lose billions of euros in gas transit charges to existing onshore pipelines.  Thirdly, the dependence of the whole continent on Russian gas will increase shortly after the adoption of the so-called Energy Union, which envisages the diversification of energy sources in Europe.  It is therefore clear that Nord Stream 2 is at odds with the EU's energy policy and, moreover, has a dubious economic justification when we consider that the first strand is used only halfway. The EU's priority should be, above all, to develop interconjectors between countries in order to increase the efficiency of the system and its resilience to possible supply constraints to certain countries.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – Nord Stream 2 is a purely political project that is dangerous not only for Slovakia, but also for the whole EU. This project goes against the basic principles of the Energy Union based on diversification of sources and suppliers. We can only achieve better energy prices by offering them more widely, not by strengthening the Russian state giant.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – I agree with what my honourable colleague Mr Kelam said on the matter, and I would like to add that reliance on Russia’s gas supply is extremely short-sighted because it is not sustainable in the long term. Primarily since Russia is not a reliable partner, but also because Russia’s supplies are limited. I believe that Gazprom is bluffing and the alleged abundance of gas in Siberia is greatly exaggerated.  It would be hypocritical and contradictory on our part to condemn the war in Ukraine and the annexation of Crimea on one hand while on the other we further increase our own dependence on Russia in the field of energy. Russia has on several occasions tried to strangle Ukraine, earlier by cutting off supply in a critical moment and now by planning to bypass Ukraine entirely in order to further destabilise them economically. Russia wields energy as a weapon without hesitation, which is why we should oppose doubling Nord Stream’s capacity, both out of solidarity for Ukraine but also to avoid ending up in a similarly precarious situation. To achieve this we need strong political means, but while we pinpoint those we should at the very least keep the current sanctions.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, a united Europe is nowadays torn by dividing lines between Member States, emerging on the path of resolving old and emerging crises. Nord Stream 2 is the project that draws a new dividing line. This time, the division is at the heart of one of the EU's most significant initiatives for a new impetus for reunification, namely the establishment of a European Energy Union, in which, on the path of solidarity and trust between countries, certainty and diversification of energy supply and competitive prices in a common energy market can be achieved. I will recall the already abandoned but priority EU-backed Nabucco project, whose fate was decided by the choice of another solution by the private companies concerned. Is it possible today to redrab europe's gas map by the consortium of European energy companies and Gazprom participating in Nord Stream? Will the EU's repeatedly declared priorities for the development of the Southern Gas Corridor be put behind again? Can governments do anything? There would probably not be such questions if information was presented to the public about why and who needs this project. It is high time for genuine openness in European energy to activate the mechanism of solidarity and trust.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail by Alain Cadec on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries (O-000052/2016 –B8—0365/2016) (2016/2532(RSP)).

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: author. – Madam President, traceability of fish products is a major issue for the Committee on Fisheries. The new common fisheries policy has very rigorous requirements in terms of marketing and traceability of fish and aquaculture products. The legislator defined both mandatory information and voluntary information for consumers, making information a crucial point of the legislation. Compulsory information is the following: the commercial designation of a species and its scientific name, the production method and fishing gear, the area where the product was caught or produced and a clear indication whether the product was defrosted. This mandatory information applies to both retail and supply for caterers and restaurants. It is critical that consumers have access to complete information in order to make an informed choice. Restaurants must always keep the information which they received when they bought the product in case consumers or state authorities ask for them. The resolution of the Committee on Fisheries discusses the Commission survey for control of 2015, which analyses the conformity of labelling with the legal requirements of white fish in retail. This sampling survey indicates that the species indicated on the label was correct in 94% of cases. However, numbers are worrying for some species, for which the level of conformity is very low: common species are substituted for more expensive species. This is often the case for bluefin tuna. In a separate study from last year on labelling in restaurants in Brussels, including the EU canteens, the NGO Oceana estimates mislabelling at 32% overall, with a mislabelling rate in bluefin tuna to be 80%. This observation brings us to ask Member States to enforce the existing law. Compulsory and correct information must be available for consumers all the way through the chain, including diners in restaurants. It is the duty of Member States to guarantee that this information is available and accurate. Member States must implement sanctions which are efficient, proportionate and dissuasive. First and foremost, Member States have to reinforce controls in order to identify fraud and the missing links in the supply chain for fishery and aquaculture products which lead to mislabelling or fraud. Further information on fish can be added to a label as an addition to compulsory information. This information can enable consumers to have complementary information such as the date of catch, date of landing, more information on fishing gear, the flag state, information on the nutritional value of the product or environmental, ethical or social information. Unfortunately, voluntary information can sometimes be difficult for consumers to interpret because of its diversity. It is also necessary that such information be reliable, meaning it must be controlled in a very strict manner. The Commission is currently working on the implementation of a pilot project proposed by Parliament last year – and my regards to our chair, Mr Cadec, who could not be here today. It deals with voluntary information on fishery products and aims at creating an up—to—date and exhaustive inventory of voluntary claims associated with fishery and aquaculture products, which are marketed in the European Union, whatever their origin. This inventory will enable an analysis of the certification systems of these claims. It could help in the creation of an external structure which scrutinises the certification of voluntary claims included on the label of fishery and aquaculture products. We are awaiting this external structure and hope that this information will be easily accessible to consumers. I would also like to remind the Commission that Parliament is still awaiting the Commission report on the possibility to define and establish minimum criteria for the creation of an EU ecolabel for fishery and aquaculture products. The publication of this report is a requirement of the common market organisation for fishery and aquaculture regulation. I would like to finish by asking all Member States to strengthen controls, because European consumers have a right to know what ends up on their plate.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would first like to thank Ms Engström and the Committee on Fisheries (PECH), in particular Alain Cadec, for the opportunity to discuss this very important issue, which, as was mentioned, concerns consumer information and the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products. Significant efforts were made in the approval of the reformed common fisheries policy to improve consumer information and the fisheries policies control regulation has critically strengthened traceability. The motion for a resolution linked to this oral question identifies the key issues, and the Commission shares with you the sentiment that we still have to do more. But we must act on the basis of evidence, rather than on the basis of emotions. The results of one study should not be generalised, especially if we have other, broader studies published during the same period which indicate that significant progress has been made.  It is the case of the EU-coordinated Control Panel for Fisheries and Aquaculture Products, which covers not only three EU canteens and some restaurants around the EU institutions, but also covers 29 countries with more than 3 900 samples. I would also like to restate that this discussion about mislabelling only covers a specific item of consumer information: the name of the food and the risk of species substitution.  Concerning the study reference, it must be stressed that its authors do not take into account the applicable legislation in its findings. Mislabelling, particularly in the case of fish substitution, does not always result from an intention to commit fraud. Incorrect labels may also be the result of mistakes or mismanagement, and these situations occur much more often than fraud. So taking into account all these elements and the relevant EU and national laws, the Commission is of the view that the actual level of mislabelling is much lower than the figure published by Oceana. So we must be careful of the evidence we use, but having said that, this is an excellent opportunity to make the point that we need a proper understanding of traceability. Traceability is a tool for transmission of information from the ship’s deck or the farm to the plate. If a solid traceability system cannot avoid misconduct of operators or human errors, it can permit us to trace back to the moment when the misconduct or error occurred. Only extensive controls by Member States can avoid misconduct of operators and more generally reduce mislabelling. Funding has already been made available through the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund to support the development, purchase and installation of components to ensure the traceability of fisheries and aquaculture products and also to support the implementation of a Union control inspection and enforcement system.  Since 2010, the Commission has assessed control systems put in place by Member States to monitor the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products. Possibly deficiencies are being addressed through appropriate means. Moreover, the Commission has started a project on compliance and control of labelling and traceability. The Commission has also been proactive in the fight against mislabelling and fish substitution. In cooperation with 27 Member States and two EFTA countries, we recently completed a coordinated control plan for white fish. As I already mentioned, more than 3 900 samples were collected, representing a broad range of products and species. This demonstrated a level of non-compliance of 6%. Just a couple of weeks before the publication of the results of the coordinated control plan, the EU-funded label fish was also completed and this finding made public. Here again, out of more than 1 500 samples from different species, countries and products, less than 5% were found to be mislabelled. So while the Commission agrees that we can and must do more, we must also not portray a misleading image of a sector that is highly non—compliant. We should not risk increasing mistrust by EU consumers, particularly as we see from evidence that the level of irregularities is generally low. It is important to mention here the different testing protocols that can be used to identify species and aquaculture products officially. It is true that DNA-based methods represent the most promising approach. The Commission’s Joint Research Centre is actively working in this field, and the experience gained in conducting the EU-coordinated control plan for fishery products will be very useful. Concerning the potential of Eco labels, I note that you consider these as one among possible solutions to avoid mislabelling, but please be aware that an EU-wide Eco label would not necessarily strengthen traceability. Having clarified these points, I am glad to inform you – as also mentioned by Ms Engström, that the Commission is finalising the feasibility report on options for a Union-wide Eco label scheme for fishery and aquaculture products. This feasibility report is based on an external study as well as on a public consultation and interviews of stakeholders. It analyses various options. I hope that this feasibility report will provide useful information and ideas to feed the debates that will take place both in this House and with Member States and stakeholders.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, as the Vice-President of our Committee on Fisheries has rightly said, we are dealing with an issue which is by no means ballad. A certain study reveals labelling problems in fishing products served in some restaurants. Data and not emotions, the Commissioner said, and so it should be. Without going into assessing that report, the data of which appear to do not coincide with those of the Commission itself, what seems obvious in any case is that we are faced with a situation which goes beyond a problem of mislabeling. We need to be able to discern whether we are facing simple mistakes or full-rule fraud. And in both cases, we are obliged to put all means at our disposal so that neither one nor the other occurs.  In the European Union we are able – and we do well – to demand the highest standards for our products and in the fisheries sector we are particularly aware of the need for this to be the case. This control must be carried out from the sea to the table and under no circumstances can we give up what should be one of our main obligations: to ensure consumer confidence.  I am convinced that the Commission is the first interested in not only not fraud, but that the consumer has full confidence. We're playing a lot. We are the world's first market in fisheries products and cannot under any circumstances allow the serious and rigorous work of the vast majority of the fisheries sector to be questioned. That is why It is necessary for Member States to exercise controls.  And when we talk about these problems, we must talk about a recurring issue and which we are calling for once again from here: the need for an eco-labelling at European level that ensures transparency in consumer information and is done on the basis of the independence and credibility of the certification process. The Commissioner said he will not solve the problem, but he will help. And I'm going to keep the Commissioner's words. These were: "We can and must do more." Let's do it.

name: Ulrike RODUST
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The findings of the study by an environmental NGO are part of a long, sad series of abuses in the declaration of food. The European Union has high standards of consumer protection. Unfortunately, however, these are only as good as their implementation. That is why we need more knowledge about where the retail chain is being tricked. At points of sale and in restaurants themselves, Member States must tighten controls to ensure that the customer is not served false fish. In addition, an improved traceability system must avoid misdeclarations at all. On these points, I support the resolution. I am only critical of the call for a minimum standard for European environmental labelling. With MSC, we have a globally recognized certification system with high standards for sustainable fishery products. A new system is therefore superfluous and would possibly be based on lower standards.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, the results of the study which gave rise to this question confirm that the control of the origin of the fish we consume is guaranteed only by mandatory rules. Today technology allows sufficient monitoring of the origin of fishery products and has developed because consumers have the right to know what we eat and because there are groups that appreciate the difference and are willing to pay for it. In addition, there are producers who are committed to turning into facts principles such as the environmental, social and ethical sustainability of their productions. Therefore, the next step, the logical step, is to support labelling with more guarantees. Because it has been shown that willfulness favors fraud and harms those who comply. There are sectors and fisheries professionals who have been demanding more rigour in the traceability of fishery products and labels for years to support the effort to add value to fish production sold fresh or processed; labels that make it clear that most of that value is left to those who deserve it most. And these are those who fish or grow fishery products using traditional and sustainable techniques and who transform them by applying those values; in short, those who work to offer quality and a differentiated product and thus maintain employment and the environment in European coastal areas. This complaint was made clear at a seminar organized by my group on December 9. Experiences such as that of the "mussel of Galicia", the first fishery product to achieve a designation of origin, or that of the "bonito del Norte", show that stricter and more mandatory labelling regulations are necessary to guarantee the origin of fish, not only fresh, but also processed, and especially in canned ones. Commissioner, if there is fraud in fresh fish, what can happen in canned fish, where the mention of origin is voluntary? Are you prepared, Commissioner, to propose the obligation to specify the origin of fish sold in canned cans?

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, when people buy, they must have guaranteed the right to decide what they eat, who they want to buy from and what kind of fisheries and economies they want to support with their choices. Because today, more than ever, buying is a political act. Reliable labelling is essential to guarantee this right, but unfortunately the results of oceana's study, published on the labelling of fish that is served in restaurants in Brussels, reveal the Commission's frequent collusion with interests contrary to consumer rights. In this case, one in three fish does not correspond to what the consumer pays. I would like to remind the Commission that it must act forcefully, because incorrect, intentional and fraudulent labelling of fish species is a violation of European Union regulations, including the common fisheries policy. It is urgent that, once and for all, fishery and aquaculture products contain clear, transparent, reliable and understandable labelling, including the country of origin, whether in the fresh market, in restaurants or in preserves and in the processed.  In this sense, we also believe that it is necessary to put an end to a confusion caused by the current labelling requirements, according to which catches from Galicia, for example, are labelled as coming from Portuguese waters or catches from Brittany as coming from waters of the Bay of Biscay.  It is also necessary to act firmly to avoid the deception of consumers and consumers, since canning brands associated with a territory can pack fishing products from elsewhere, without indicating the origin, as has happened, for example, with mussels in Galicia.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a huge variety of fish species are consumed in the European Union and more than 65 % of them are imported. So there is a need and a demand from consumers to have more information about these species, and they need to find it on fish labelling. It is a question of having access to clear, honest and complete information about the foods they buy. The replacement of one species by another, as well as being an economic fraud, is also an environmental problem, since it allows species that are threatened or illegally caught to enter the market, and this obviously also poses a risk to the health of consumers. Cases of substitution of one species with another, whether by mistake or by fraud, can be detected, for example, by DNA, which is not a practice at present, and which is quite complicated research, but which, as the Commissioner said, can still be carried out.  Our political choices must aim at a clear objective, which is to achieve traceability that helps prevent false or incomplete labels and to keep illegally caught fish out of the market, while providing consumers with more information. We also need help from technology, as someone has already said, to study innovative systems that are not easily circumvented. Some examples are already there. At the same time, we also support the idea of a European Ecolabel for fishery and aquaculture products, but with clear and shared criteria, given that 38 % of the participants in the consultation promoted by the Commission think that there are already too many eco-labels and almost a third think that we cannot trust the existing ones.

name: Werner KUHN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner Vella, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his In Germany there is a winged proverb, that is, "the customer is king". And the customer is the consumer, and the consumer has a right to know what he is buying for a variety of reasons, and he enjoys it. Fish and fish products are particularly concerned with ensuring that the quality is right and that the price is right. However, the consumer is also increasingly very ecologically oriented and I believe, Commissioner Vella, that we have already made a sensible start with the directive, which is currently still based on voluntary action, with regard to the traceability of fish and fish products, including in processing.  It is good that we now have this test and also knowledge that some things are not going as we imagined. Wherever large quantities are imported – and we are the largest import market for fish and fish products in the European Union with 500 million inhabitants – such things also come to light with criminal intent. And if bluefin tuna in particular is declared incorrectly – 30 000 tonnes may only be caught and consumed by this high-quality species worldwide – no idea, perhaps 50 000 or 60 000 tonnes – then we also know that there are specific irregularities in the import sector. In the case of products from South-East Asia coming from the aquaculture sector, we must pay particular attention to the fact that there is fairness here and that there is a level playing field. Our small and medium-sized fishing companies are following this certification and I very much support the eco-label that has been launched.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President; Commissioner, the Oceana study, which has been much in the debate, is probably not as comprehensive as the Commission is doing or covering so many aspects; probably, but it has a virtuality and a value, which is that it has motivated us all to hold this debate here today, it has led us to put to public debate a question on the labelling of fishery products, both fresh and - I would also say - transformed.  We need to achieve – and for this we must improve the regulations – a complete traceability from the sea to the table. I agree with one of the aspects you have said, Commissioner: eco-labelling is not going to help traceability, but we do already need the feasibility report of the ecological system, for which they committed themselves in Article 36 to which it would be on 1 January 2015, and we do not have it. And to tell him that there is mandatory information on labelling that confuses: the determination of the FAO area confuses consumers; the Gulf of Cadiz and the bank of Galicia, as Colleague Senra has said, are in the name of the FAO area as Portuguese waters, and it confuses consumers. That needs to be changed because it's uns needed information and it's leading to great confusion.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Madam President, the fish and agriculture products offered for sale to consumers in retail catering or canteens must be properly labelled. Unfortunately, in recent years the so-called seafood fraud, the selling of seafood products with misleading or no label, has become a widespread form of food fraud. Not only does it threaten the bottom line of honest fishers and seafood traders, it also undermines the objectives of the CFP, the progress made by the sustainable fisheries, and it can allow illegal and unregulated fishing practices to go undetected. Our question today is based on the recently published study concerning restaurants in Brussels, but the truth is that a global analysis suggests that over 30% of seafood products are mislabelled. And I believe we all remember what happened in 2013 with the horsemeat scandal, which shocked the European food industry. It emphasised the challenges in monitoring every step of the complex global food chain supply. The importance of traceability through all stages of production, processing and distribution rose on the public and political agenda. Do we need to repeat this scandal again before we draw certain conclusions? I hope not, because it is important that we secure sustainable sources and that these sustainable sources provide the proper legal labelling.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Oceana's study is certainly partial, but it is nonetheless disturbing and it is disturbing inso far as it gives a picture of how consumers have been deceived or deceived in a city such as Brussels, which is a symbol of the European Union.  We have talked about the importance of informing consumers in all forums, and we have been focusing for a long time on the need to disseminate clear and precise information on the origin of food products, because responsible and conscious consumption is a political and social choice that all citizens have the right to exercise.  Despite all these demands, we are often at the starting point. It is intolerable that food fraud should continue, but it is also intolerable that very important information should sometimes be omitted. I am thinking, for example, of squid bleached with oxygenated water in order to make them more attractive, without the consumer knowing. Of course, consumer education is also essential, but the two must go hand in hand. With this resolution we are once again affirming the need to trace products, in this case fish, from the origin to the moment they arrive on our tables.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Madam President, although traceability of fishery products is mandatory by European legislation in order to ensure that a particular product can be identified and its production, handling, processing, packaging and dispatch process is known, the results of a recent study by an NGO indicated that about one third of the samples were found to be serious errors in the labelling of fish served in Brussels , including in the canteens of the European institutions. If this is happening in the heart of Europe, from which this legislation emanams, then let us imagine what may be happening in the rest of our Union, with serious consequences for consumers, but above all with serious harm to our fishermen, who see in this way their income diminished by illegal and unfair competition, especially through the mere substitution of low commercial value species processed , for example, filleted, and coming from countries with standards much lower than ours, thus paying for one thing when, after all, another is eaten. It is essential to comply with what is legislated and to ensure traceability of fishery products, from the boat to the plate, i.e. it has to be an ongoing process throughout the row, because only then will we be able to prevent fraud and unfair competition.  Not only should we address issues related to food security, but also the control and sustainability of fisheries resources, as the implementation of traceability systems should ensure comprehensive monitoring of catches, leading to the consequent sustainable exploitation of fisheries resources. On the other hand, in order to finally guarantee the added value of high-quality fishery products caught with sustainable and environmentally friendly fishing gear, as is the case in the Azores, where, due to this unfair competition, the commercial value of the noble species that are caught in their waters is not compatible with their enormous quality and sustainable fishing methods.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Union is the world's largest importer of fish and has fleets operating globally. This alone requires traceability of the characteristics, origin and type of processing to which aquaculture resources are targeted.  I come from the Azores, an outermost region of Europe, where the sea has high biodiversity but low biomass, and where it is captured by an artisanal fleet what some of the great chefs classify as the best fish in the world. I therefore feel particularly sensitive to this problem.  It is up to the European Union to monitor the mechanisms used to certify and identify the processing of products and to protect the quality of origin and the quality of our craft fleets.  I must also stress that it was not any administration or authority that alerted us to this matter, but a non-governmental organisation for the environment. This reinforces the need to stimulate citizenship in Europe.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, the rules set out in Regulation (EU) No 1379 on the COM for fish products must be met in the European Union. It will help, as has been said, improve product traceability and transparency in the market. I also take this opportunity to stress the need for rigorous control of imports at all ports of the European Union and thus prevent the entry of products from illegal fishing and those that fail to meet phytosanitary standards, social, environmental standards, etc. I would like to mention two other points set out in the Resolution, Commissioner. On the one hand, the presentation of the Commission's report continues to be pending by considering the possibility of implementing eco-labelling for fisheries and aquaculture products. Secondly, I would also like to ask you, in addition to other voices that have already spoken in this regard, to consider a solution to avoid the confusion that may give rise to the consumer the mandatory indication of catch areas in cases such as Spanish, which is the name of 'Portuguese waters', which encompasses much of the Galician coast and also of the Andalusian coast.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, the European fish consumer is being the victim of fraud. There is talk of error rates of up to 95% for tuna marketed in Brussels, but this is not an isolated case: the same is the case in Spain, Ireland, Greece or Great Britain. We could solve this by providing accurate information on the species and origin of the products; we could solve it with the labelling, of which we are pending; something relatively simple. For example, in the case of preserves, we would protect the consumer, but also sustainable European production such as Galician mussels. We must demand greater clarity and transparency in information on the origin of fishery products. If we want to protect our quality productions and protect consumers, we must clarify the origin in labelling.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the cases of inappropriate labelling of fish observed in Brussels restaurants confirm the need for traceability of fishery and aquaculture products. Initially, in accordance with fisheries legislation and the Community control system, all consignments of fishery and aquaculture products should be traceable at all stages of their production, processing, distribution and marketing - from fishing or cultivation to retail sale. In addition, undertakings marketing these products should provide all necessary information to the competent supervisory authorities on the traceability of the products. Of course, the Commission should take immediate measures to comply with the rules on the traceability of fishery products in restaurants and to always provide appropriate information to consumers. At the same time, the supervisory authorities should assess the potential risks in order to avoid disruption of trade. After all, the application of traceability rules not only satisfies legislative requirements but also helps to recall products that are in trouble.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: – Madam President, I will not repeat the arguments of my colleagues which I accept, but I believe, fellow members, that it would be a great mistake for this debate to be, in fact, a label of the wrong behaviour of European industry because the rule is: fair behaviour, respect for fishing principles, but in so far as a non-governmental organisation and other disparate studies show some dysfunction in what the Commission and European fisheries policy actually promote , I believe that it can only be regulated by improving control and by a somewhat more compliant need for labelling. These situations that we encounter, error or fraud - it is up to the control to decide what it is about - but there are no situations that are a rule in the behaviour of the fishing industry in the European Union. Of course, most problems must be recognised as occurring in imports and there, perhaps, the Commission will have to find a solution in order to have much more appropriate control to meet the normal principles of respect for consumers and product quality. I believe that, Commissioner, it is, in fact, a debate that demands more concern for the European consumer and then not only you, but also the Commissioner for Consumer Protection must give an answer.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, recent studies have revealed alarming cases of errors in the labelling of fish served in restaurants, resulting in the representation of misleading information to consumers. This is happening at a particularly historic time when the availability of fish within the European Union is decreasing while consumption is increasing. Around 65 % of the fish consumed in Europe are therefore imported, leading precisely because of the lack of strict import controls, which are important risks to the health of European consumers.  The Commission and the Member States must improve the measures to implement measures to ensure the traceability of fish served in restaurants, with particular reference to the Regulation on the common organisation of the market and Article 36 on European eco-labelling for fishery and aquaculture products. The genetic barcode should be used more effectively as a traceability tool for fishery products. This is an innovative method capable of identifying fish species with a degree of reliability far greater than the other diagnostic methods used, which can therefore become an indispensable tool to combat fraud against consumers and to implement greater controls capable of raising the levels of hygiene, health and product quality of fish products.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to make some final considerations. First I would like to repeat that this discussion about mislabelling only covers a specific item of consumer information, that is to say the name of the food and the risk of species substitution. No study puts into question the consumer information requirements established by EU legislation.  I have to clarify also that the Commission is in no way trying to underplay the results published by Oceana, although I insist that we have more accurate studies and reports which, unfortunately, no one is referring to. Having said that, the Commission even took corrective action following the Oceana report. The Commission reminded its catering contractors of their duty to fulfil contractual obligations and tighten controls on fish product labelling in its canteens. A project for sampling in view of DNA identification of fish species is planned for 2016. As an additional measure a project for sampling in view of DNA identification of fish species is planned for 2016 in coordination with the JRC and other Commission services. Ms Engström also stressed the role that the Member States have to play in all this and I totally agree. In fact Member States must ensure traceability in restaurants, particularly under the framework of the CMO Regulation. The Control Regulation provides for a sound enforcement of the traceability requirements by the Member States which shall ensure that appropriate measures are systematically taken, including administrative action or even criminal proceedings in conformity with their national law against natural and legal persons suspected of a breach of any of the rules of the CFP. There was a remark made by Mr Kuhn that the consumer is king and I totally agree and that is why I tried to clearly explain that we must not portray a misleading image of a sector that is highly uncompliant when the evidence shows that the level of irregularities is low. We should not risk increasing mistrust by EU consumers, especially when bluefin tuna was mentioned because it is a fact that bluefin tuna is one of the highly traceable species globally. I can also assure everyone, especially our colleague Ms Briano, that Brussels is in no way trying to trick any consumers. Outcomes of audits carried out for 2010 and 2015 have allowed the identification of weaknesses in traceability of fish products and these were mainly due to gaps in exchanges of information especially and the identified deficiencies are being addressed. The recent modification of the implementing rules of the Control Regulation should also technically allow the improvement of interoperability of IT systems between the Member States. I would like to thank all those who took part in this debate and I would also like to thank you for the amount of comments and suggestions that you made and that we have noted.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The new Common Fisheries Policy includes strict legislation on the marketing and traceability of fisheries products. We found that the average rate of labelling fraud is 3.5%.  This leads us to demand that Member States enforce the law. Mandatory information must be available to the consumer. States must ensure that this information is accurate and available and put in place proportionate and deterrent sanctions against fraud. I want to go beyond the minimum criteria to frame existing labels.  A European public label for fish products would enable reliable information based on a coherent component of sustainable criteria and which will be recognised by consumers. A single European label would guarantee compliance with high environmental, social and health standards. I would like to end by asking the Member States to strengthen controls, because European consumers need to know what is on their plate!

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. – Recently, an NGO released a report on irregularities in the labelling of fish and seafood in Brussels. Unfortunately, this problem is common even in the restaurants of the European Parliament. More transparency is needed within food chains and in the case of fish, being a product that is easily perishable, traceability is essential to guarantee food safety. There are many irregularities within the EP, the degree of food waste is absolutely revolting, and the fact that there is no traceability on the fishery products consumed in our institution itself should make us question serious questions about management within Parliament. I hope that both the European Commission and the Belgian Government will take this issue seriously and resolve it as soon as possible.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. – This week, the European Parliament will vote on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail. The European Parliament resolution supports the introduction of a reliable system of traceability from landing to consumption in order to ensure consumer confidence and consequently reduce dependence on imported fishery and aquaculture products, thereby strengthening the EU market.  I fully support consumers' rights to information and strengthen national controls, and I call on the European Commission and the Member States to consider possible measures to improve the traceability of fishery products. I particularly support the creation of the EU Ecolabel in the field of fisheries and aquaculture.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
