text: The next item is the joint debate on fisheries Partnership Agreements: – Jarosław Wałęsa's recommendation, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia (13015/2015 – C8-0402/2015 – 2015/0224(NLE)) (A8-0142/2016) and – Gabriel Mato's recommendation, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, concerning the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol establishing fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Islamic Republic of Mauritania for a period four years (12773/2015 – C8-0354/2015 – 2015/0229(NLE)) (A8-0147/2016).

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the first ever EU fisheries agreement with Liberia and its Associated Implementation Protocol were signed and entered into a provisional application in December 2015. Their conclusion will be subject to the approval of our House this coming week. It is important to sustain a good relationship with Liberia. Therefore, this sustainable fisheries partnership agreement (SFPA) will be a very good tool to do so, but I believe it will also benefit the European Union as a whole. The EU and Liberia already cooperate through multilateral agreements such as the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. In addition to that, Liberia cooperates with the EU in terms of fighting against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.  The new agreement will provide a framework for taking into account the priorities of the reformed CFP and its external dimensions, with a view to establishing a strategic partnership between the European Union and Liberia. The main objective of the new Protocol is to provide fishing opportunities to Union vessels in the Liberian fishing zone. The Protocol offers opportunities to 34 tuna vessels from Spain and France based on the reference tonnage of 6 500 tonnes per year. In return, the EU will pay an average annual contribution of EUR 650 000, split equally between access rights and sectoral support for Liberia’s fishing policy. The aim is also to enhance cooperation between the EU and Liberia to promote a sustainable fisheries policy and a sound exploitation of fisheries resources in Liberia’s fishing zone in the interest of both sides. I therefore encourage this House to vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, just a few weeks ago we were talking in this plenary session about the external dimension of Community fisheries policy and supported a change in the strategy that should serve to give more guarantees to our fleet, more transparency to agreements and improved conditions for both the European Union and the third countries with which we signed agreements. Well, the Fisheries Protocol with Mauritania, which we are talking about today, is the finding that we are indeed taking steps forward and in the right direction. We have been able to sign a much better agreement than the previous one, both for the European fleet and mauritania and its inhabitants, who will be able to benefit not only from the economic counterpart agreed by the catches, but from the support of the European Union to contribute to its development. As will be put on the table throughout the discussion, this new agreement with Mauritania resolves some gaps in the previous Protocol, the usefulness of which left much to be desired. The restrictions imposed on the fleet then resulted in a weak use of the possibilities of capture, which were also greatly diminished after the elimination of a traditional fishing for the European fleet such as cephalopods. Fishing areas for the seafood fleet and for small pelagics have been adjusted to improve cohabitation with Mauritanian fleets and fishing opportunities for black hake trawl fleets and bottom longline fleets have been increased. The way in which the obligation to include Mauritanian personnel in European ships has also been improved, solving problems related to the level of qualification of Mauritanian sailors. The new Protocol also includes improvements for fleets of highly migratory species, as it may be carried out under conditions similar to those applied by other third countries, as control and access measures have been harmonised with those established for other tuna agreements. In the temporary area, it allows fishermen in the European Union to fish in Mauritanian waters for a period of four years; a breakthrough without a doubt. Until now, being more time-limited, there was a situation of negotiating the renewal of the agreement at about the same time as it came into force. These are therefore substantial improvements for our fleet and mauritania, and they will strengthen relations and solve, as I said before, some problems that also arise with regard to the fleet of third countries that worked in the same waters. On the economic point, the conditions agreed in this new Agreement substantially improve the cost-benefit ratio, which is also contributed to changes in technical measures. This Protocol has been being implemented provisionally since November 2015 and, so far, we can say that there is a good balance sheet, although at the end of this May we will hold a joint committee to analyse its progress and propose some improvement. Among them, something that the Commissioner has heard many times: the possibility of including that cephalopod fleet and that can return to Mauritanian waters. We know that it was one of the gaps in the Agreement and we understand that at the moment there are conditions necessary for this activity to resume, but we also know that Mauritania opposes and we are aware that its inclusion will be very difficult. In any case, we want to talk to you in this joint committee, even if we are not as optimistic as we would like. Another key issue: the possibility of introducing downloads of some of the catches at European ports; in the specific case, ports of the Canary Islands, Luz and Las Palmas. In principle, despite the Union's requests, only downloads were introduced in Mauritanian installations. We believe , and so does the Commission believe , that this exception can be considered, at least as long as Mauritanian port infrastructures are developed.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a pleasure to jointly debate the Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement (SFPA) and associated protocols with Liberia and Mauritania. I would like to take the opportunity to thank both rapporteurs, Mr Wałęsa and Mr Mato, for their reports. I am pleased to note that the Committee on Fisheries also recommends that Parliament give its consent to both agreements. Let me now say a few words on each one of the agreements. I will start with Liberia. The new Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Liberia is not one of our largest agreements in terms of fishing opportunities and in terms of financial layout. However, it is a very significant agreement because it expands the EU’s regional network of tuna agreements into West Africa.  The protocol to the agreement will last for five years and will allow up to 28 EU tuna seiners and six surface long liners to fish in the Liberian fishing zone. These vessels also operate under other agreements in the region. Therefore, the agreement with Liberia will contribute to extending the geographical coverage of fishing activities without increasing the fishing capacities. This agreement with Liberia also fully respects the principle of sustainability of fishing activities. It is based on the best and latest scientific data and the principles of transparency and non-discrimination with other foreign fleets. A human rights clause has also been included. The agreement also sends a strong signal that Liberia is open for business despite the difficult situation in the country after last year’s Ebola outbreak.  The Fisheries Agreement is a real partnership. It not only brings fishing opportunities for EU vessels and steady financial revenues for Liberia, but it also forms a framework for developing the Liberian fisheries sector and to fight illegal fishing together. The sectoral support available to Liberia under the agreement will be used to help reinforce its monitoring, control and surveillance capacities. This will enable it to control the fishing operations of all fleets operating in its waters and of its own fishing and carrier vessels, wherever they operate. Additionally, recent discussions with the Liberian authorities have opened the way to a complementary action under our development cooperation programme with Liberia to enhance the sectoral support under this agreement. While this is at an early stage, the Liberian authorities have requested additional support for, in particular, capacity-building, artisanal coastal fisheries, post—harvesting handling and local markets. I am confident that this new agreement with Liberia will develop into a long lasting partnership. Let me now turn to the protocol with Mauritania. The Fisheries Agreement with Mauritania is the European Union’s biggest sustainable fisheries partnership agreement in financial terms. It provides fishing opportunities to up to 98 EU vessels from 11 Member States and is therefore of crucial importance for the European Union fleet. The new Protocol is the result of intense negotiations. It is a significant improvement compared to the previous protocol and can be considered an example to be followed for the negotiation of future SFPAs with other countries. The new protocol is fully consistent with the external dimension of the reformed Common Fisheries Policy, as was also mentioned by Mr Mato and Mr Wałęsa. It respects the principle of sustainability and confirms the principles of transparency, preferential access for the EU fleet and non—discrimination between foreign fleets. The protocol will ensure good returns on EU taxpayers’ money and gives the EU fleet stability and predictability with improved technical conditions. It will ensure better implementation of sectoral support through more conditionality.  The focus now is on ensuring the smooth implementation of the new Protocol. I can assure you that the Commission will monitor closely the state of all the stocks covered by the protocol in order to ensure the sustainability of fishing activities. We will also check whether Mauritania respects the principles of transparency and non-discrimination. I think this is crucial to ensure that the EU fleet is not operating under less favourable technical and financial conditions than other foreign fleets. I consider it a very positive sign that Mauritania recently adhered to, and took a leadership role in, the Fisheries Transparency Initiative. I know many of you are interested in the first meeting of the joint committee, scheduled to take place at the end of May. I hope that at the meeting we can approve the sectoral support programming under the new protocol and wrap up sectoral support from the previous protocols. But we also intend to raise with Mauritania the possibility of creating a new demersal fishing category. Such a new category could benefit the trawlers which are currently unable to fish for octopus and other cephalopods due to the bad state of the stocks. We will also discuss the possibility of relaxing the obligation for EU pelagic vessels to trans-ship 100% of their catches exclusively in Nouadhibou.  Let me thank you again for today’s opportunity to debate these fisheries agreements with you. I look forward to your support in the future on these agreements.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: draftser of the Opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, in the Committee on Development we are fundamentally concerned about two issues when we face these fisheries agreements between the European Union and third countries, developing countries. The first is sustainability; sustainability to prevent overexploitation that could prove catastrophic for some of the species in these fishing grounds. Secondly, those States that sign these agreements with us make a profit that can avoid the economic dependence they have been suffering so far.  That is why we welcome these development support clauses which will enable both Mauritania in this renewed agreement or new agreement, and Liberia in this first agreement, to improve its economic situation and, above all, its own development as autonomous countries that they are. Secondly, that these clauses have also been involved in the issue of transparency and monitoring of the monitoring of agreements. We therefore welcome these two positions and welcome the conclusion that this agreement takes into account those things which are so essential for our committee.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Mr President, the Fisheries Agreement between the European Union and Liberia will certainly provide more opportunities and predictability for EU vessels and also for the industry in general.  From the perspective of the Committee on Budgets I have to say that the financial impact of this agreement upon the budget of the European Union will be EUR 3.25 million for the five years in which the agreement will be applied. Besides the access of EU vessels to Liberian fisheries resources, it is very important to note, as the rapporteur has also done, that half of the total contribution will be devoted to supporting the implementation of Liberia’s sectoral fisheries policy.  In a country where approximately half of the population lives on the coastline, and where the fisheries sector is an essential part of the economy, it is very important to achieve the objective of developing responsible and sustainable fishing activities while ensuring that the sector reaches its full potential. A key element, in my opinion, will be the monitoring of the implementation of these measures in order to make sure that the money is well spent, that it achieves its purpose, and that no fraud with EU funds takes place on the ground.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, from the point of view of the Committee on Development, the two fisheries agreements with Mauritania and Liberia represent a step forward. These are countries that are trying to rise again after passing hard tests such as war, epidemics and human rights violations. There are positive signs coming from both countries: reforms such as the abolition of slavery and torture in Mauritania or those on transparency and good governance initiated by Liberia. However, there are still countries where humanitarian aid and development cooperation are still needed in order to eradicate poverty, hunger and economic inequality.  The European Union continues to enter into different fisheries agreements with individual countries that share the same resource and the same sea. I would like to ask the Commissioner when we are going to start promoting a regional fisheries agreement that includes all the countries concerned together. As a member of this Parliament's Committee on Development, I must point out that, despite these agreements being addressed to developing countries in need of humanitarian aid, our opinion is limited to giving the committee's consent or not, renouncing the valuable contribution resulting from the committee's work.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: PPE Group. – Mr President; I would first like to congratulate you, Commissioner, on the policy of concluding fisheries agreements. They are of vital importance to our fleet, but also to the development of the third-country fisheries sector, through funds for sectoral support. I encourage you, Commissioner, to continue along this line. The fisheries agreements with Mauritania and Liberia, although different from each other, are both important for the European fleet, including in my region, Galicia. Tuna, as has been said, is the main target species in the Liberia Agreement; it is a highly migratory species and that is why it makes every sense to foster a network of fisheries agreements in the area. The Protocol with Mauritania, as you said, Commissioner, is one of the most important that the European Union has. It is true that substantial improvements have been made from the previous one, but I have to regret, once again, the exclusion so far from the cephalopod fleet. In addition, the joint committee meeting, to be held on 30 and 31 May in Brussels, will address fishing opportunities for freezer trawlers of demersal species other than black hake. I would like, Commissioner, that scientific studies on the analysis of these stocks may be ready for the meeting. Depending on their results, fishing opportunities could be granted for this trawling fleet. Ladies and gentlemen, I conclude; the European fleet carries out sustainable fishing within and outside our borders and is the most controlled in the world. I therefore hope that Mauritania's surpluses in certain fisheries will not be granted to other less sustainable fleets, as has happened in the past to the detriment of stocks and also to our fishermen.

name: Ulrike RODUST
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Fisheries Partnership Agreements with third countries are an effective way of ensinnating the main basic principles and values of the reformed CFP outside Europe, thereby promoting the sustainable management of the seas worldwide. For this to work, the agreements must formulate and implement clear conditions on sustainability, fairness, coherence and transparency. The two bilateral agreements with Mauritania and Liberia have taken two important steps towards a sustainable development of fisheries outside the EU. For the first time since 2007, an agreement with a new partner has been concluded with Liberia. I am pleased that the EU is making a significant contribution to the development of the fisheries sector on the ground and to the fight against illegal fishing. I can call the Mauritania Protocol the compass for the EU's external fisheries. I would like to emphasise the transparency rules in particular, which are groundbreaking for all future agreements. The Protocol requires the publication of all Mauritania's public and private fisheries agreements with third countries. The transparency rules are essential to determine how much fish is actually left for the European fleet without depriving Mauritanian fishermen of their livelihoods. That is the core of my understanding of sustainable fisheries with third countries. I therefore support both agreements.

name: Czesław HOC
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Sustainable fisheries partnership agreements between the European Union and the Republic of Liberia and Mauritania are accepted and should be good agreements, for the words and phrases themselves – i.e. partnership, sustainable fishing, cooperation in combating IUU fishing, scientific cooperation, coherence of fisheries policy, synergies of actions, non-discrimination of other fleets, continuous monitoring – indicate that the benefits are mutual and good for the conservation of living resources.  I have one comment, and at the same time a request and an appeal. Well, together with the tuna fishing, unwillingly, we catches a large number of sharks. And although many believe that shark is a bloodthirsty beast, even such a view does not empower man to the barbaric method of so-called "shark finning", that is, cutting fins and throwing the live body of a shark back into the water, which causes its slow riding in torment. We know that there is a total ban on shark finning on ships in European Union waters, and I am not sure that such a ban will also apply in these agreements. Hence my request and call for the Joint Fisheries Intelligence Committee to do exactly that and to carry out a thorough review on this issue.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: on behalf of the ALDE group. – Mr President, the Agreement with Liberia is a beneficial agreement for both the European Union and Liberia. I would like to point out a few things that I think are important in this agreement. Firstly, the manner in which fishing authorisations given to Union vessels are granted, solely on the basis of this agreement, to exclude the granting of private or bilateral ones, I believe that it will give a chance to comply with the common fisheries policy and will particularly help to combat illegal fishing, where Liberia has made significant progress in recent years. I believe that the funds that the Union will allocate to Liberia in this area will be spent for the benefit of the Liberian industry and will add to this industry from which a large part of the population lives. I also welcomed in agreement the way in which the European Commission will involve Parliament, we will be informed about the progress of this agreement, it ensures transparency, and I believe that it is the only way in which cooperation between Parliament and the Commission in these agreements is not a formal one, but an effective one.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The FISHERIES AGREEMENT between the EU and the Republic of Liberia concerns tuna and for a period of five years. I welcome the agreement because it calls for greater transparency and sectoral support for the fisheries sector in Liberia, an important aid for developing the country's own capacity.  It is hoped that the support provided by the EU for the development of the fisheries sector will increase scientific estimates of fish stocks, support local coastal fisheries on which the local population depends and strengthen monitoring and control to combat illegal fishing. As far as transparency is concerned, this agreement is in line with the best agreement to date, which is the signed agreement between Mauritania and the EU. One clause states that Liberia should openly publish any fisheries agreement it signs, both private and public, with the foreign fleets fishing in its waters. Liberia has also done this exemplary for several years. We are looking carefully at this example and also wish that the published information is both complete and reliable. The agreement with Mauritania is a good agreement in many respects that has become a symbol of external fisheries policy, in which the EU seeks to raise standards and force other fleets from nations such as China, Taiwan and Russia to adapt to more sustainable conditions.  Mauritania promises to publish all fisheries agreements signed by the country. It is hoped that this will increase the transparency of the overall fishing pressure so that we have better management of the fishing resource. The agreement does not include squid, as Mauritania has been clear that this must go to the needs of its own people. This is very good and should be respected by all foreign fleets fishing in Mauritanian waters.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, another month, another waste of time, effort and resources coming to Strasbourg. Another ditched Cameronian promise to the British people – and another fishing agreement! Or rather, two: one new with Liberia and one renewed with Mauritania.  This is another betrayal of ordinary people. These agreements are a form of euro-colonialism. They allow the EU to plunder the fish from other people’s waters, while salving their consciences. How much local fishing does not happen because Europeans steal the fish? How many Africans remain poor? How much of the EU conscience money actually goes to help ordinary people?  There is an old joke – actually a proverb – which says: ‘Give a man a fish and you feed him for a day. Teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime.’ Not with EU fisheries agreements, you do not! Instead you take from him his living, his food, his livelihood and you line the pockets of the political class of the country concerned. And they tell us that we are the mad ones who want to leave the EU. I want Scotland’s 200 mile limit back; Brexit now!

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, since 1989, the European Union has been signing fisheries agreements with Mauritania. The last one was on July 10, 2015 and will apply for four years. This is a good agreement, as it allows European vessels to go fishing in Mauritanian waters, while respecting a sustainable fishing objective. It thus limits the volume of fish devoted to freezer trawlers to 247,000 tonnes, compared to 300,000 tonnes in the previous agreement. In return, the EU will pay Mauritania 55 million euros a year, compared to 67 million euros in the previous agreement. However, Mauritania is a poor state, which ranks 161st in the world on the Human Development Index. That is why the 2015 agreement gives it additional financial assistance of 4.125 million euros per year, instead of only 3 million in the previous agreement. In addition, the 2015 agreement maintains the obligation to recruit 60% of Mauritanian sailors. It is therefore a fair agreement that serves European interests, while respecting Mauritania. I hope that this agreement will mark a new beginning in our relations with Mauritania, relations which have lacked mutual trust in recent years. I particularly wish this for two reasons: first, as a Frenchman, because Mauritania is a French-speaking state that is the friend of France. I myself went to Nouakchott on an official mission a few years ago and I was admirably received there. I would like to do so, secondly, for our collective security, because Mauritania is an exemplary partner in the fight against Islamist terrorism, and we have a strong interest in supporting such a reliable ally.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would also like to greet the two rapporteurs of the agreements under discussion. As shadow rapporteur for the Socialists and Democrats for the fisheries agreement with Liberia, I was concerned about aspects related to the transparency of the relationship established, respect for Liberia and the values of the European Union, including human rights and labour rights. I was also concerned about the adequacy of the funds involved and the respect for environmental standards generally established at international level. The Republic of Liberia has experienced extreme difficulties in recent years, involving internal conflicts and instability of government institutions. After two civil wars and hundreds of thousands of dead, Liberia's economy and also its politics are slowly recovering.  Personally, at no point have I had any doubts about the support to be given to this fisheries partnership agreement, the first and only one that Liberia has. For this country in the structuring phase, it is crucial to stimulate relations that strengthen ties with the international community. Both fisheries agreements under discussion here - Liberia and Mauritania - allow the expansion of fishing opportunities for EU fleets, use only renewable biological marine resources that are not used by each country, open doors to cooperation with local industry and increase food security in Europe.  So you have my full support.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to conclude and support the signing of these fisheries agreements between Liberia, Mauritania and the European Union from the sentiment and reason. Because, as a bermeana and as a member of a family of fishermen, I share the joy that these agreements have produced in professionals and shipowners of my people, and the joy that they will have generated in other European fishing areas that work in a difficult sector that needs hope and opportunity and ask for and deserve the respect that they are earning at a pulse for their responsibility and good practices. And because, thanks to these agreements, 124 European vessels will be able to operate in these fishing grounds; but they also remain committed to sustainable fishing, the development of local communities and the fight against undeclared and unregulated fishing.  Feeling and reason, because the facts show that not only the European fisheries sector but also local communities and the seas around the world need this policy of agreements claimed by all stakeholders.  In Liberia we made our way for the first time; in Mauritania we reissued one of the most important agreements, pending solving the issue of cephalopods, so important for the Canarian fleet. In both cases, we improve control over fishing activities, cooperation policy evaluation procedures and economic endowment for fisheries owners: a much better picture than where these agreements are replaced by other less social and less sustainable farming formulas.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you for the work done by the Commission and the rapporteurs. The same principles and rules must apply to the European Union in partnership agreements as fleets in European waters, and that is right. And when fishing in third-country waters, adequate support must be provided for local fisheries for sustainable development. We are having a positive interface with countries that need this aid in some way, and for us the issue of human rights and the mutual responsibilities of Europe and third countries remains a priority issue. We therefore welcome the work done by the Commission in including these issues and criteria. I believe that it is particularly important to continue to check, before and after, as the agreements provide, that the contributions made by the European Union in exchange for fishing rights actually reach the local populations. We cannot close our eyes to the fact that our large industrial fleets are taking resources from these seas, and there must be benefits for the local people. We hope that this fisheries agreement will above all improve the current situation for Liberia, which is a recovering state.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the two rapporteurs on the outcome of these agreements, which are very important to the European fleet and, of course, to the Spanish fleet. And I therefore welcome and show clear support for these two agreements with Liberia and Mauritania. I believe that these agreements have substantially improved other agreements and I think we are on the right track. Agreements for the European fleet are very important, but I believe that making improvements as important as those in these agreements also makes a difference. I would like to say that I regret , Mr Mato referred to this , that it does not enter, that the cephalopod fleet is excluded. I sincerely regret it, because they were in the previous Protocol and have now been excluded. I don't know if it will be possible to introduce them - I don't think so - but in any case, I think it's important and I wanted to mention it. The next joint commission on 30 and 31 will also discuss the introduction of the category of demersal fishing freezer trawlers. It is important that they are introduced if, of course, scientific results support it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, the adoption of international fisheries agreements is always good news and, therefore, it is good news that agreements have been reached with Liberia and Mauritania. It is good news for the European fishing fleet - we were talking about more than 120 vessels – but it is also good news for the development of the countries with which the agreements are signed and are therefore positive.  I do not want to go into the debate anymore, in more detail, but I would have liked, it has been said, that the Mauritanian Agreement would have envisaged the cephalopod fleet. It is very important — of course it is for my land, for Galicia — and that is why I wanted to raise my voice so that, if possible, this claim will be taking into account, and at the same time encouraging you, Commissioner, to continue working in this direction to reach new fisheries agreements.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – I do not come from a maritime state that would benefit from this fishing in the African seas, but I nevertheless support these two agreements. I support it for a simple reason, because it is very clear from the words of both the Commission and the rapporteurs that it is taking care of both.  Both, on the one hand, for the European naval fleet, the fishing fleet, for sustainable fishing in this part of the seas, and above all, the important part that also speaks to development aid to these countries, because we know that we are talking about African countries that have been affected by various problems, from diseases to other shortages. And I am convinced that, with every agreement we work with this continent, we must be aware that our fair and quality humanitarian-development aid will be the best we can do for these countries and, on the other hand, for Europe. I will support both agreements.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, fisheries contribute to job creation in many countries, inside and outside the European Union. A reasonable Union external fisheries policy must safeguard the interests of European fishermen, especially smaller ones, and require sustainability, food safety and the fight against illegal fishing outside the European Union. The European Union, Liberia and Mauritania fisheries partnership agreements must therefore include clear clauses on the protection of fish stocks, the fight against illegal smuggling and unregulated fishing, but above all, Mr Vella, respect for fundamental labour rights in the activities of fishermen in these countries. In particular, it should be noted that Mauritania is a country where, Mr Vella, there is a slavery regime for 150,000 people of the Haratin tribe, i.e. 4% of the population! This is unacceptable and the European Union must now condemn and avoid any agreement with Mauritania. What do you have to say about this, Mr. Vella? Will you sign a fisheries agreement with Mauritania, a country in which there is slavery? I am waiting, Commissioner, for an answer on this issue which is particularly serious.

name: Werner KUHN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Vella, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his First of all, congratulations to Mr Mato and Mr Wasa. You have done absolutely good work here and have put the partnership agreements with third countries of the European Union on a new level of quality – together with the Commission. I think it is very important that we do not lose sight of the fact that, as international regulations define it, fish is a common good. It is a protein carrier that is indispensable for feeding the world's population.  And with countries that are unable to use their own resources – for whatever reason: because their fleet is too small, because they do not have the right technologies – with countries such as Liberia and Mauritania, we are entering into contracts with a very specific background: the financial benefits are paid there so that the small and small-scale fishing fleet can develop. , so that people are able to provide for their income and nutrition again. That is a very important point. And if we fish here sustainably, according to the rules of basic regulation that we have laid down, we are three times better off than if we make contracts with nations that do not comply at all, for example with countries from East Asia and Russia.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their constructive comments and suggestions. These two sustainable fisheries partnership agreements are both significant steps forward for different reasons. The agreement with Mauritania is the biggest so far. The agreement with Liberia will bring fisheries revenues and support fishermen in a country which is still reeling from last year’s Ebola outbreak. In both cases, all parties will all gain from reinforced monitoring, control and surveillance, from more transparency, from more predictability and from the better access and agreements that they will bring about. They provide the value for taxpayers’ money that you have called for. From your comments I can conclude that these partnership agreements are strongly supported in this House, and I would like to make some additional comments. A number of Members – including Mr Sebastià and Ms Briano – questioned the sustainability of these agreements. Yes, the sustainable fisheries partnership agreements concluded between the EU and these countries constitute a highly regulated and transparent framework for the fishing activities of the EU fleet in third-country waters. These fisheries partnership agreements form a legal framework which aims to ensure that the fishing activities of the EU fleets are respectful of stock status, of the environment and ecosystems and do not compete with local fishermen. The EU is leading by example in this respect, and no other fleet in the worlds has set the same standards of transparency and good governance in third-country waters. A number of Members – Mr Millán Mon, Ms Aguilera García and Mr Blanco López – spoke about cephalopods, and here I have to say that the most recent scientific assessments indicate that the corresponding stock is still over-exploited. Moreover, Mauritania confirmed its intention to reserve this fishery for its national fleet, thus no surplus is available and no fishing opportunities could be negotiated. However, the European Union will continue working with Mauritania towards the adoption of adequate management measures for the recovery of this stock. There was a mention of sharks, I think Mr Hoc mentioned the issue of sharks, and here I have to say that the EU fleet does not practise shark-finning whether in the EU or outside in non-EU waters. A number of MEPs also mentioned the artisan fleets, and I have to say that the sectoral support budget in both countries has earmarked amounts for their artisan fleets as well. With regard to Maria’s comment on slavery, these agreements are not only helping the EU fleets, but also helping these countries. Helping these countries hopefully helps them remove and solve their social problems.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for contributing to our debate this evening. Every single voice was important because it gave us additional input to what exactly we want with these unique and sustainable agreements with these two countries. My only wish is that, at some point in time, at least one of our debates about fisheries could take place at a more reasonable time of the day instead of just before midnight.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President; Thank you, Commissioner; firstly, too, to thank everyone who has intervened and, as we have seen, tomorrow we are going to vote on an agreement which has been difficult to negotiate and even more so to sign, but which is extremely positive. When we talk about Mauritania we are talking about a country with many needs, but as with many countries in Africa, also a territory with great possibilities and with which the European Union must strengthen its relationship. At this point I would like to highlight how we have been working for many years from the nearest European region, the Canary Islands, which develops, with the support of the European Union itself, some really interesting projects of collaboration with Mauritania, such as the recent Macapel, which opens up many opportunities for both sides. But, Commissioner, I'm worried about something. It seemed to me to understand that he was resigning, or that it was claimed that 100% of the catches have to be made in Nuadhibu, and the possibility that they could be made in the Canary Islands was being closed. I don't think we can resign ourselves. We have to negotiate. They know that being able to make landings in the Canary Islands is not only possible, but also does not harm them and is even good. Therefore, let us not give up in advance and move on with it. If we can resolve these issues, I am sure that we will definitely be closing an excellent framework for all, which must also serve as an example for the agreements signed by the European Union with other third countries. That is why, from the European Parliament, we encourage the Commission to continue on this path of transparency in all bilateral negotiations. And I conclude by asking you for your support in adopting this Recommendation, and I would like from here to thank the committee and all the people of this Parliament who have long helped to seek the best agreement and in the best conditions to successfully resolve this matter, as demanded by Community fishermen.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is one-minute interventions on important political issues.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Mr President, I am here to defend eighty-five workers, eighty-five jobs from the company Industrias Lacteas Vallisoletanas which the French group Lactalis puts at risk. A plant with a turnover of more than 50 million euros, a profit of two million euros in 2014 and an annual production of more than 94 million liters in 2015.  The collective redundancy dossier submitted is based on organizational and productive reasons; never economic, as the commercial has historically yielded profits. We are witnessing a planned relocation process by desizing production volume from the plant to hurt its costs. Why is that? Because they are more concerned about their benefits than the workers, and they are also denied interlocution.  I therefore ask the European Commission to take all necessary measures to prevent such practices that destroy our business fabric. I ask for protection for workers and publicity for this effrone. They say "Lauki doesn't close" and I say with them "no, it doesn't close Lauki".

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Mr. President, after last week's leak, the TTIP debates have boiled over again. Citizens have the right to information and express their opinions on the basis of it. Those of us who ultimately decide with the media have a special responsibility. In this case, however, populism also harms because in addition to interpreting facts in particular, it weakens our negotiating position. And it needs to put the betterment of citizens and the protection of our standards, in particular regulatory cooperation, social and labour rights and food safety at the heart. In addition to this in the context of the negotiations, Croatian priorities are access to sources of financing for SMEs, removal of existing administrative barriers for export, transposition of product protection labels, compliance with the precautionary rules around GMO and visa waiver for our citizens. European negotiators need to firmly defend the EU standards, which we have been creating together for so long. It is up to us to support them in a constructive way. Only if we succeed, will TTIP get my support.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, the Spanish Government celebrated World Press Freedom Day last week ordering the cessation of Basque public television broadcasts in Navarra through DDT. This signal, which provides the information and television offer with extensive programming in the Basque language, is easily disseminated under the same laws in other autonomous communities, so the measure is discriminatory and arbitrary. Technically, it is unjustifiable, and politically, incomprehensible, because Navarrese citizens have supported these issues through majority agreements of their Parliament. In short, while technology opens the door to freedom of expression and information, while offering great support for linguistic and cultural diversity and enviating Basque television around the world, an authoritarian and anti-European decision narrows freedom of expression and information.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, in recent days, Turkish provocation towards Greece has exceeded all precedents. By challenging the sovereignty of inhabited islands in the Aegean or even in the Libyan Sea, with low-altitude overflights over Greek islands and violations of Greek territorial waters. This behaviour by Turkey constantly poses risks for new air or naval accidents during the planned intercepts by the Greek aeronautical forces under international law, as has happened repeatedly in the past. The main thing, however, is that Greece is thus obliged to pay high defence costs, which burden its budgetary problems and have historically been one of the main causes of the country's over-indebtedness. Since the European Union requires the reduction of Greek defence spending in the context of the evaluations of the Greek programme, it must take a correspondingly more active role in the fight against Turkish aggression.

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Mr President, last year I warned this Parliament about the dangers to children who are being swept onto the shores of Europe in the migrant crisis. I warned about the thousands of boys and girls who were disappearing, taken by traffickers across a Europe without frontiers. Now, the numbers of lost children have multiplied and Interpol has warned in January this year that 10 000 children have vanished. 5000 have disappeared Italy alone. One thousand are unaccounted for in Sweden. Europol’s chief of staff has said, ‘we just do not know where they are, what they are doing or who they are with’. Angela Merkel and other open border fanatics told the world that all could come. The sex traffickers – the men who supply the paedophiles – have accepted that invitation. This is a sacrifice of children for European ideology, and this Parliament does nothing.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, on Europe Day, from this European Parliament, I would like to point out two things. First, the European Union is living through difficult times. In the face of this, we must remain Euro-cryptic and move away from Euroscepticism. Our problems can only be fixed with more Europe, not less. The European Union is our great project and must become a benchmark for all in indissoluble areas such as sustainable well-being and the promotion of human rights in the medium term.  Second, as a Catalan citizen in this House, I would like to express the strongest commitment of my fellow citizens to work for a more responsible and more supportive Europe, a Europe of citizens who defend justice and freedom. Catalonia will be able to be better involved in this task when it soon becomes a new European state.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, 178 million hectares of forest are currently in the European Union and my country, France, is the third largest country on the surface.  Unfortunately, the wood sector has lost nearly 500,000 jobs in ten years in France and the closures of sawmills or carpentry are going on. Until recently, in my department of Meurthe-et-Moselle, a sawmill has closed its doors in lunévillois with some thirty jobs lost. This sad observation is only the result of the dumping orchestrated by China to which we export our raw wood en masse at paltry prices to return them to us processed. A pragmatic and job-friendly ecological approach would require that raw materials, in this case wood, be produced, used and processed as close as possible to their place of use and not sent to the other side of the world to return as manufactured products. Many states are now contingent on exports to a China that subsidizes these companies massively. The Union forbids us its practices in the name of ultraliberal dogma. That's why I think it's time to change the method. Our sawers, our jobs and the planet will be better off.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Mr President, you decide as the European Parliament to rename today's anniversary, 9 May, the day of the anti-fascist victory of the peoples to the day of the European Union, the birth of monopolies. You are re-writing history, equating fascism with communism, escalating anti-communism, supporting the persecution of communists in many countries by setting up fiestas and houses for counterfeiting European history. Objectively, you cultivate ground for the revival of fascism that gives birth as a reserve to capitalist rot and barbarism. You can't change history, you can't erase popular memory. We honor those who fought Nazism – fascism in every way then and now. The communist parties heroically led the national liberation and anti-fascist movements, the titanic struggle and sacrifices of the Soviet Union of millions of Bolsheviks and Soviet people who nailed the red flag to the heart of the Nazi beast in the Reichstan. History doesn't go back. The 21st century is the era of victorious socialist revolutions for social liberation.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Today we celebrate Europe Day. Every year, on this day, we wonder where we are and how to solve our challenges, our problems. But we seem to have accumulated a particularly large number of them this year. We can't find the right solutions and we can't find unity.  And we all know that Europe must change – urgently, immediately and now, because the way it is cannot survive. However, although we are talking about important things such as migration, such as the economic deep crisis, we must not forget the other projects we have set ourselves. And at that end, I would like to draw attention to our European Monetary Union.  The accompanying programs we're doing are not enough. We must be aware that if we are to maintain the European Monetary Union, all countries will have to make the necessary reforms. It will cost us a lot of effort, of course, but we believe it pays off. This is a major project on which Europe must persevere.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Mr President, the European Commission proposed the liberalisation of the visa regime for citizens of Georgia travelling to the EU last month. The European Commission's proposal comes after a careful assessment of the progress made by the Georgian State in implementing the reform measures needed to reach this point. Georgia's progress in recent years has been noted by the European institutions and I believe that the European Parliament and the governments of the Member States must support the European Commission's proposal. Romania, in particular, has been and is a supporter of Georgia's European aspirations, in particular for the implementation of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement and the Visa Liberalisation Action Plan. Moreover, most European states have been able to see the positive developments in Georgia and the determination of that state to achieve the criteria required by the European institutions. I thus understand the aspirations and expectations of the Georgian people on this moment.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: – Madam President, rural mountainous and remote areas are facing an energy crisis or energy poverty, and one of the dimensions of this poverty is the low level of energy efficiency of residential and commercial buildings, which in conditions of lower incomes and increased consumption makes the situation of the population living in the area even more difficult. I therefore call on the European Commission to define specific programmes in existing EU funds programmes that would facilitate and enable better energy efficiency, which means simplifying the process for using these funds and also an information campaign that would allow people living in these areas to know and use these funds more and make energy efficiency large enough in these areas to enable people to live better.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, today there is seventy-one years of victory against fascism in Europe, seventy-one years of the peoples' victory for their freedom and for justice in the face of fascist horror and barbarism. My country, Spain, was sacrificed in the Cold War, with Franco becoming one more piece of the Atlantic board in Europe. But he lived in our people the same spirit and hope of his European neighbors: to resist and fight oppression and live in democracy. Today, however, it is Europe itself that betrays its working classes, which denies bread and dignity to its children, which points to migrants rather than welcoming them, which ultimately feeds the monsters it claims to combat, as evidenced by the new rise of the far right on a continent devastated by the austerity and disaffection of its citizenship. I want to vindicate today the memory of those who fought fascism, because their combat is more alive than ever, on the street, in the neighborhoods; by another policy based on work and its rights; because only the organization of the working class can overcome the hydra of fascism.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, Commissioner Pierre Moscovici has just said that refugees support growth. According to him, the reception of migrants is indeed one of the reasons for the economic growth that will reach almost 2% in 2016 in the euro area. He estimates that public spending on migrants has - I quote - a boost effect on the economy, which he estimates at 0.3% of GDP in the European Union and even 0.5% in Germany. The reality is very different. Several studies have shown, in recent years, the catastrophic consequences of immigration for France. A 2012 study by Jean-Paul Gourévitch put the budget at 17 billion euros. A 2013 study by André Posokhow even estimated it at 84 billion euros, taking into account all the extra costs induced by immigration on the police, justice, health, education and housing. The conclusion is necessary once again: the Brussels Commission is lying to the peoples of Europe.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Mr President, 23 million European citizens are currently unemployed and 76 million are few - or are not - qualified. Behind these figures are human dramas. Our social model is trembling, we must prevent it from faltering. The European quality framework for apprenticeships, developed by the European Trade Union Confederation, attests to this: long-term alternating training with enhanced mobility is a royal path to employment. Learning must be shaped according to the specific needs and skills expected in the labour market. Social partners, training organisations and public authorities must carry out this work together. If future European initiatives, such as the Agenda for New Skills for Europe, attract learners to general education and also vocational training, socio-economic success will be on the agenda. The European Union needs positive political projects and projects, so let us seize this challenge to meet it in a concrete way!

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, during this bloody crisis, hundreds of thousands of Spanish families have been evicted from their homes and the only answer they have encountered in the Spanish Government is passivity. In my country, millions of people are also suffering mortgage abuse by draconian soil clauses and the only answer they have found in the Spanish government is passivity. In Spain, judges cannot paralyze the sale of a homeless family's home while analyzing the validity of a contract, and the only answer they have found in the Spanish government is passivity. That is why, Mr President, I call for decisive action by the European Commission to stop this situation.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr These are very sad reports that come daily from the OSCE Special Monitoring Force in eastern Ukraine. The ceasefire in Ukraine is being violated at increasing intervals, which means that violence around contact lines has reached alarming levels. Moreover, artillery and mortars are used almost daily, which is a clear violation of the Minsk agreement, and we — the EU — are just looking at.  Let me be clear; I welcome the agreement reached within the framework of the Trilateral Contact Group on the introduction of a ceasefire during the Orthodox Easter and holidays in May, but I think that we three European institutions, led by the Commission, must demand more, we must use this opportunity to restore a full ceasefire.  People in eastern parts of Ukraine are living in very difficult conditions, a huge humanitarian crisis. The reports coming to us are even.m. difficult to read. We have a duty to do everything we can to push for a permanent ceasefire.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, an tseachtain seo caite do reachtálas éisteacht phoiblí sa Pharlaimint ar ábhar baincéireachta poiblí. Le linn na héisteachta bhí deis againn foghlaim faoi na buntáistí go léir a bhaineann le baincéireacht phoiblí. Tá go leor leor modhanna éagsula gur féidir linn a chur i bhfeidhm chun córas den saghas seo a bhunú in Éirinn.  I gcomhthéacs na hÉireann, bheadh sé tábhachtach comhoibriú a fháil ó Oifigí an Phoist agus ónar gComhair Chreidmheasa. Tá an iomarca smachta ar fad ag na bainc phríobháideacha ar an ngeilleagar, go háirithe leis na rátaí úis atá comh hard. Agus cad ina thaobh go mbeimisne ag tacú leis na bainc seo a ghoid go leor airgid uaidh ár dtír cheana féin agus gan aon bhuntáiste ann don ghnáthdhuine? Táimidne i Sinn Féin go hiomlán i bhfabhar forbairt ar bhainc phoiblí chun cabhrú le gnóthaí beaga a fhorbairt. Táimid dírithe chun fíor-athrú a dhéanamh agus tacaíocht a thabhairt dár SME’s, do na Comharchumainn agus don gheilleagar sóisialta. Is trí fhorbairt ar bhainc phoiblí a thiocfaidh an t-athrú seo agus caithfimid tús a chur leis láithreach.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Last Wednesday, the Governing Council of the ECB abolished the five hundred euro note in its omnipotentity and self-aggrandism. The argument is that the ECB is concerned that this banknote encourages criminals, terrorist financing and money laundering. Seriously, do we really believe that a criminal stops being a criminal because instead of two five hundred euro notes, he now needs five two hundred euro notes and two instead of a suitcase of money? Nobody really can tell us that. What is really at stake is monetary policy. The ECB and Mario Draghi must push through negative interest rates. After all, if you no longer receive interest on your savings book, but have to pay interest, you will run into the cash and withdraw the money from the account. So what the ECB decided last Wednesday is the official start to the abolition of cash. Cash is freedom. I want to get cash. If you want to get rid of cash, it's totalitarian.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Last year, we in Parliament for a long time coordinated documents with which we gave clear starting points to the European Commission on how it can negotiate on our behalf, on behalf of The Europeans, around the transatlantic agreement.  In recent days, we have witnessed again the media's reports of classified documents, that greenpeace representatives, other opponents are telling us about this... However, the Commission simply does not come before Parliament or inform the current public what is going on in these talks. Unfortunately, the lack of transparency is one of those matters that is the greatest threat to this agreement for my notion.  I therefore appeal to the Commission to first of all assure Parliament that all obstacles, all the problems that we have raised – particularly in the area of food safety, the environment and the like , are taken into account. In the following, it informs both Parliament and the public and that Europeans will not depend on non-governmental sectors and on certain classified documents.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, on 9 May, exactly 66 years ago, the Schuman Declaration laid out a vision for peace and reconciliation in Europe, rising from the ashes of war and genocide. That vision of solidarity was the foundation for the European Union.  As we mark Europe Day, we are sadly once again seeing mass atrocities, genocide and war crimes taking place on our borders, with xenophobia and racism on the rise across Europe. The EU must act in line with its historic heritage and formulate a clear policy and plan of action to stop and prevent genocide and mass atrocities around the world. I have been engaged with the European Grassroots Antiracist Movement, joining a network of parliamentarians working to raise awareness and commemorate genocides in Rwanda, Bosnia and Armenia so that we can learn the lessons of the past. We must use this terrible history as a platform for intercultural dialogue and exchange. Never again!

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, at the end of April Croatia was hit by a big cold followed by frost and fruit, vegetable and vine plantations in central and northwestern Croatia were almost completely destroyed. The current damage, in which 90-100% of the projected fruit crop has perished and up to 90% of grape and vegetable yields are estimated at around EUR 15 million. In addition to Croatia, this sudden chill has caused unprecedented damage to our neighbours in Hungary, Slovenia and Austria. Following last year's crisis caused by the Russian embargo still in force, which has hit European fruit and vegetable producers, this natural disaster is a new coup and could mean their end if we do not urgently help them. We ask the European Commission to financially support farmers affected by the natural disaster and respond positively to affected Member States seeking assistance. This is the only way to save European fruit and vegetable production and protect European consumers from price increases that could occur due to a lack of domestic production.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, this is an important time for the development of postal and delivery services across Europe. Our EU laws in this sector have been under review, and we shortly expect a proposed measure on parcel deliveries from the European Commission. In fact, EU rules protect the right of households and businesses to reliable and affordable letter and parcel services. Contrary to what we are told by Eurosceptics, these rules do not require privatisation of our postal sector, and let us not forget how significant our mail is for jobs and also in terms of new technology and internet-based economic activity. Physical products we buy online still need to get to us in real life.  Around 1.5 million jobs in the EU are provided by postal and delivery services. We want the sector to thrive through long-term investment and the creation of quality and sustainable jobs, not through increasingly precarious employment arrangements. I and many Members of the European Parliament – more than 50 – also support the Keep Me Posted campaign to ensure that people can make proper decisions about how they receive key information affecting their lives. Please join us in supporting this campaign.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, exactly sixty-six years ago, Robert Schuman spoke his vision for a safe Europe. It was five years after the end of World War II, and Europe was recovering from the traumas of war. Politicians questioned how not to repeat the same horrors. Schuman formulated his vision as follows: "Par la mise en commun de productions de base et l'institution d'une haute autorité nouvelle, dont les décisions lieront la France, l'Allemagne et les pays qui y adhéreront, cette proposition réalisera les premières assises concrètes d'une fédération européenne indispensable à la préservation de la paix." Sixty-six years ago, it was therefore clear that the road to a safe Europe would not be a one-off and simple one. It is good to recall this long-standing effort. Back in communist Czechoslovakia, I dreamed of the free life we experience today. The founding fathers had courage, and we must have it, too, today, so that we are not afraid to thank them for it and continue these efforts.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, I would like to refer in my statement to the question of the return of property in Romania. I chose this subject because recently a Euro-Member from Hungary has caused serious image damage, accusing Romania of discrimination against the Hungarian minority and the Reformed Church. I want to inform the European Parliament that Romania, like the other former communist countries, addressed the issue of restitution after 1990. Obviously it was and is a difficult process, by some estimates, in January 1990, there were about three million people in my country as tenants in nationalised buildings. We can't play with people's lives, especially since a lot of them were older people. It is true that the procedure was also cumbersome for the fact that many heirs submitted incomplete documents, but there is no evidence, none, that the principle of ethnicity or cult was applied in the process of restitution, as the Reformed Church complained. On the contrary, we recently saw in a small town in Aiud how the building returned to the Reformed Church endangered the lives of six families, with ten minors, by disconnecting from the electricity. I believe that the best evidence that Romania has not discriminated against any minority is the decisions of the European Court of Human Rights.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Yesterday, the day of the destruction of Nazism was celebrated throughout Europe. This is a huge event in the history of all mankind. In my country, Latvia, this day, the victory over Nazism to celebrate rationally is both on 8 May and, as several families do, also on 9 May. Just imagine, colleagues, also in this late hour in Riga and other cities of Latvia, the squares are full of people, as people continue to celebrate the victory over Nazism.  Europe was born after the destruction of Nazism. The European Union project is the idea of Europe with solidarity, of Europe with brotherhood, of a Europe without borders, so in my view today, as never before, is our duty to show solidarity with the people who have lived for decades in Latvia and Estonia with the non-citizenship of Latvia and Estonia, and to necessarily grant them the right to vote for the European Parliament. Thank you!
